After watching many reviews on youtube, I decided to take a leap and buy "The Wrath of Ashardalon". I like the idea there is no dungeon master and you could play this solo.Box Opening/First Impressions:My first impressions upon opening the box was that of a kid at Christmas, with lots of beautiful pieces. Dungeon tiles, to amazing artwork on the cards, very nice looking rule book, etc etc. The figures could be used for your regular D&D; games and are high quality for plastic models.All the components are sturdy and well made which should stand up over time.Game Play:I have played many scenarios and I would prefer a bit more narrative. They give you the overall game feel about a village needing help from a dragon and then there is a few sentences about the scenario you have chosen, but not much more.However, I am a bit disappointed. "TWoA" seemed rather simplistic; draw a monster card, move, kill, deal with a "encounter trap", rinse and repeat. You don't really gain much XP, treasure or much for killing monsters, traps or any other deed. I have heard this game was BASED upon the 4th Ed. D&D; rules. Much of the game play was simplified as well. I guess this is my concern and I have tried to remedy this with some alterations.Playing games like World of Warcraft and Skyrim has made my idea of what a fantasy gaming should be? Because in many video games there is much more to do to keep you vested.I know I can hear some people say, that there are other scenarios like "rescuing villagers", but really the different scenarios are much the same. I have heard you can use other pieces and elements from the other D&D; board games.... but... I just wish there was more depth here.I have been altering the game to make it more flavorful and interesting like making more Encounter cards. I have taken the 3 good cards in that deck and made more of them (treasure, healing potion). Thus making the characters deal with more than just being attacked at every corner. I also have bought real metal coins for treasure so the "clinking" sound of loot makes it more fun. I plan more altering in the future to keep the game fresh and fun.In Summary:As Tom Vasel (from the Dice Tower) said in one of his game reviews, "people often don't like games due to their preconceived ideas they have or what they wish a game would be"... and I would generally agree with that. I do enjoy this game and I appreciate the quality of the game pieces and artwork. This game basically has made it possible for someone like me to run a D&D; type game, even if I am a bit disappointed, I still enjoy this game. The price of the game is a bit steep for being so old. Still, the good replay value, the quality of the pieces made it a fairly good deal.One quick side note: Check out Mage Knight board game (by WizKids), another fantasy game that is awesome and good for single players.
I've been looking for a way to introduce my teens to D&D. This is a visual D&D lite and perfect for introducing them to ideas and mechanics that I've enjoyed for many years in my gaming.
summary: Excellent product and everything I wanted it to be

reviewText: Great game and great replay value.  Play alone or with up to 4 friends (5total players).  Takes from 30mins to 120mins tops so not all night and if you want to play longer u can play another adventure.  Clean-up can be a bit of a pain but not a big deal.

from all 3 of the board games this one is the hardest and best by far. Legends of drizzt is too easy if you play as drizzt. Please do yourself a favor and get this game! good for all types of people.quick to learn and widely played. You do not have to role play with this game, so people who choose not to will still have the same amount of fun.
summary: Best fantasy board game there is.

reviewText: As they say it is similar to Hero Quest... super-powered.  My only complaint: WotC.  Next product would be monster and hero expansion packs as a supplement.

i havent had a full chance to play with it yet but it is pretty cool. all the figures (even though unpainted) and neat and well sculpted. im getting in to the hobby of painting figures so the fact they are unpainted does not bother me. they are also very useful for any type of d&d campaign you are trying to do

For those just getting started in the DnD world or those who haven't played DnD in years if not decades this is a good way to get learn/re-acclimate yourself to the games. Played an adventure with a friend on the first day. While the amount of pieces, tokens, tiles, was a little overwhelming at first, got accustomed to the game pretty quickly and had quite a bit of fun.My only con about it is, that Ashaldaron(the figure) seemed well it had great detail on it, but the assembling in factory seemed bad or poor. There is a slight gap between the two sections and what appears to be a slight overflow of glue that was used. I guess I kind of expected a one piece mold or if not a bit more care taken when assembling. I do plan on painting these figures at some point and I'm not sure whether this is normal or not. As well as whether it will be possible to really paint this particular figure without it looking off due to the gap/glue problem. Perhaps I got a bad piece, I'll probably end up talking to customer service about this issue and see about getting a replacement that was assembled properly.

This is a sealed booster box. It contains 36 booster packs. Each pack contains 15 cards. This was a balanced set featuring cards from previous core sets and a few new ones. I bought it to rebuild a discard deck that left my possession when I broke up with a girlfriend. We never bough a booster box, but oddly enough, I managed to get the same mythic rare cards (Garruk Wildspeaker, Ajani Goldmane, 2 rare Liliana's Caress, and a Phylactery Lich. It is odd that I somehow managed to get those, but I am extremely happy about it.

For some odd reason all of a sudden I had a hankering for MTG Gaming.  Something that I hadn't touched for years and years.  So yes I got caught up and decided to purchase a whole box.  I got a few good cards and built a deck.  Off I sent to a local shop to join some Friday Night Magic fun and experience something new.  It was certainly an experience and I was definitely the prettiest girl at the school dance.  Not that I was the most popular from a card aspect ( my cards could not compare to the years of collection and hardcoreness of the other MTG players) however I was definitely the prettiest.

It's great!36 boosters that is 36 rare cards since each booster has a rare.Great chance of getting a mythic since it's all boosters.Tons of fun opening each one and anticipating getting something good.If your store sells boosters for 2.50 you are over paying a little, but I know lots of stores that sell for 3 dollars or 4 so it defiantly worth the price.
Got a few mythics a couple planeswalkers and plenty of great additions to my collection. Just a little bummed I didn't get a Baneslayer Angel though, but hey, someone else may be lucky and get 2

I love this set, it has amazing figures, the game itself is ok by far but i got it for a DnD game me and my friends have, so i can use from out of the book things in this game, i tried to figure out how to contact the people on amazon but couldent, if you see this please message me because it is missing a Legion Devil piece, i'd really like it if you guys could send it to me.

Even though M2011 is cycling out soon enough [It's replacement, Magic 2012 is due out in July], it was a fun set to play.  If you're getting a gift for your child and they're just getting into Magic, the Core sets are the way to go.  Cards are a bit simpler but there are still many excellent cards and it's a great starting point.  Plus, every kid loves Titans.  My box came from a third party seller in pristine condition.
Bought this with friend to draft.Core set is nice because it features balanced distribution across all colours and makes for funnier draft.
summary: Perfect for a couple of draft

reviewText: Anything under $105 is a good price. This is the current Magic core set through Oct 2011. Good value considering "chase" mythic rares are Primeval Titan ($40) Frost Titan ($20) Baneslayer Angel ($20) and a few others in the $5-10 range. On average you get one foil rare, two to three foil uncommons and 4 foil common cards per box in addition to the 36 rares (which include 4-5 mythic rares) per booster box.Booster boxes are good to buy if you're starting out or if you don't have a lot of cards, but if you already have a fair amount of commons/uncommons you're better off financially to just buy the single cards you need.Anyone that plays magic casually or as a hobby would be happy to receive a *SEALED* booster box as a present. There is a proven way for people to dig through the box and take the "good" packs out of a box that isn't sealed, so only buy complete booster boxes that are sealed!!!
summary: 36 packs=37 total rares, with an average of 4.5 mythic rares per box

reviewText: Very Pleased with this box, I was chasing a few cards and trying to complete my collection. This core set has some really good cards for casual play and formats other than standard. The quality of the artwork on these cards is amazing.

I just started collecting/playing MTG again and decided to buy a few boxes - the Core Sets bring back back a lot of the older cards back into play ie. lightning bolt, juggernaut, etc.  and then there's the newer model of cards that features planes walkers and titans, i actually got a Primeval Titan & Baneslayer Angel in my booster pack along with planes walker; was to happy to see that.Overall there isn't much bad news from this core set from what i can tell.  gives a lot of options for standard play and there are no over powered cards.would be nice to grab for gift those just getting into the game.
This is available at time of posting for 29.99 through Amazon under a different listing. Great item if you can get it for the right price.Magic Gathering 2011 Core Pack
summary: CHECK FOR OTHER OPTIONS ON AMAZON

reviewText: Good alternative to some of the long war games out there (Axis and Allies)  However , not quite as strategic as Axis, it does play out in about an hour or so.Excellent historical settings for each battle, and you get to chose your battle scenario.maybe 60% luck, 40% strategy,  which is ok, heck monopoly games can be 80% luck, so a good balance.

This mini is intended to be the centerpiece in your E1-E3 D&D; 4th Edition campaign.Starting with Death's Reach the players learn the very foundation of reality is threatened by those seeking to usurp the powers of the god of death. To prevent this cosmic coup, players must trace the disruptions into the Shadowfell's timeless core, where all things find their end.In Kingdom of the Ghouls demonic forces plot to usurp the Raven Queen's power over death, and all paths lead to an ancient kingdom hidden in the subterranean depths of the Shadowfell.Finally in Prince of Undeath the demon lord Orcus tries to usurp the Raven Queen's power over death using a shard of evil plucked from the depths of the Abyss. Only the world's most powerful heroes have the slightest hope of stopping him.The mini is a fantastic sculpt and has a great paint job. It is also HUGE!! It may be rather pricey, but you can blame Wizards for that. This was apparently a limited production run and there were allocations everywhere. Everyone I've called is sold out, so it's Amazon or Ebay and that's it.

I remember when the original version was released. Having always been interested in the civil war, I badly wanted it, but I was too young. Now some 10 or 11 years later, I own the much better reissue version. I have been after this game for some time now, and it was well worth the long LONG wait! I purchased "Battlelore" a few years ago so I had an idea of what to expect from battle cry( since it uses the same type of game board and similar figures and rules). But even with the similarities, battle cry is much more different than I thought.The rules are easily learned and make the game very enjoyableThe plastic soldiers are don't feel as durable as the battlelore troops, but for the most part are very sturdy, and add a type life to the game( especially when painted)I saw a review that said the flags don't stick well. Sadly this true. It does'nt take away from the game at all, but it is somewhat annoying. It is easily fixed however. Some people have glued them and they hold together well.Also, a good paint job will help the flags better stick to the pole and when it is hardend it makes the soldiers feel more durable. Not to mention adding even more life to the game.The details say it includes 122 miniatures with 61 for each side, but while I was setting up, I noticed that there were more union infantry that confederate. In fact there is 1 odd man out who I just use as a generals aid. It may just be an error on the manufacturer. Anyway, like I said, the rules are easy and enjoyable, the board is nice and really big, the scenarios are outstanding and the game overall is very fun. Even the box looks good. I will be playing this game til' I die.

It's a lot of pieces. Received it, opened the outside packaging, and put it down. Pieces, pieces, pieces, and I'm not sure it's worth it. Why don't they give you a summary of the game on out outside of the package. Now I don't know it it can be returned.
Simple but fun. Has enough different battles so you shouldn't ever get tired of playing. Is a good game for teens to play as well as it is not difficult to understand the rules.

Wizards of the Coast's "Battle Cry" is a fun light war game set in the Civil War.  One player commands the Confederates while the other commands the Union.  The board is divided up into three sections- the center and the flanks.  Various units- infantry, cavalry, artillery, and generals- populate the board according to each scenario.  Players play cards which tell them on which section of the board they can move units for attack.  Players then roll dice and whichever symbol pops determines if an enemy takes a hit or is forced to retreat.  Each scenario is based upon an actual historical battle such as Shiloh or Antietam, and terrain hexes are placed upon the board to recreate the battlefield.  From the same designer, this is a very similar system to "Memoir '44" and "BattleLore," though of course the historical theme differs.  All told, "Battle Cry" is a lot of fun, though may be just a bit too light for heavy wargamers.
summary: Fun Strategy Game in the Mold of "Memoir '44" or "BattleLore"

reviewText: I ordered this game for my son and he has enjoyed playing the board game with his best friend. They like the game.

My husband and son (12 years old) enjoy this board game.  They are both Civil War military buffs, but that's not necessary for this game.  Each round is based on actual battles, but the outcome depends on the players' strategies.
summary: Great strategy board game based on Civil War battles

reviewText: Much easier to play than i thought.  Every game is different. The game system is very cool.  The board and pieces are striking.

Dear you guys. Words cannot express how much I hate you guys. As we fight our way northward into the great unknown, only that one thing remains certain: that I hate you guys with every tired muscle in my confederate body. We have taken Topeka and I must rally the men onward to Missouri. Because I will not stop until we have won it all, and you guys are my slaves. Because I hate you guys. I hate you guys so very very much. Yours, General Cartman Lee.
summary: Long live the Confederacy...Respect my authority...

reviewText: I played only one battle and I must say the game plays smoothly and is a lot of fun. Yes a lot depends of the cards you get and luck but it is card driven game. I like it. Components are nice the only issue are the flags but after using a drop of glue they stick nicely. Map is beautiful and once you set the game up it looks impressing. This game gives you possibility to teach your buddy in 5 minutes how to play and fight couple quick civil war battles in one evening. Simply brilliant.

The best Civil war board game I have ever played! I love American civil war era games and this one is the funnest. My friends and I like to modify games and with this one we just purchased 3 of them and put all three boards together to make one giant board game. Each board is considered a flank in the game and we combine the cards. This allows us to play with multiple people usually 4 on 4 with one on each side being the general issuing the orders to the other players. Excellent game!!! well worth the money and easy for younger children to understand and enjoy as well.

My 9-year old son and I play this regularly.  We have been big fans of the Memoir '44 board game for years now, and this is very similar in rules, albeit different given the era battles it represents.What has surprised me is how much this game has kindled an interest in the Civil War for my son.  He now checks out Civil War books from the school library frequently, and at a recent book fair, gravitated to a few history books about Abraham Lincoln and Tecumseh Sherman.  He has even tried his hand at re-creating a few scenarios for the game pulled straight from his own history books.  Since its built on C&C; rules, you can't fully recreate all battle scenarios.  But enough to at least get the 'flavor' right.  So in that regards, this game is almost a form of edu-tainment.I've only one gripe about the set, and its one that has been repeated by others.  The little sticky flags are awful. They fall off all the time.  You'll need to invest in some super glue and spend an hour or so re-applying them.  Better yet, use the glue when you first put them on to save yourself the hassle of having to re-apply them later.  The flags add a lot of color to an otherwise "dingy" looking game (tan, blue and gray are the predominant colors obviously).  The flags also give you good sight representation of battle scenarios, so you'll definitely want to keep them looking good.But overall, a great addition to our gaming night rotation.
summary: Great historical choice for Commands and Colors series

reviewText: I liked this product because it's a nice representation of combat from this time period. The manual is packed with different historical situations and the rules are simple to learn & explain!A match can take anywhere from 30-60 minutes, so it's not extremely long. If you wanted more entertainment then it's easy to reset and rematch.My only critique is that Battle Cry is only for 2 players, so that may be a let down for those who have larger parties of people. You could try to have it be 2v2 and make the players on one side work together and agree upon strategies. I don't think this point merits removing another star though.
summary: A Fresh Addition to my Collection

reviewText: I found this little gem to be a great game!It is simple enough to be learned and played quickly, yet detailed and versital enough to start and stay interesting. The game is definitely an abstraction of Civil War tactics, so if you're into minutea and detail-like Squad Leader, you probably won't care for this game too much. But, if you can stomach the idea of relatively unit sizes (the rule book states that in some scenarios the units can represent regiments, but in larger scenarios those same units can represent entire divisions) and scope of battlefield, you'll probably like this game. While it is somewhat simple, I still think it does a good job of capturing the essence of being a Civil War Battlefield commander. And if you're a history buff, the scenarios all have a quick historical background.Let's open the box, shall we? The pieces are pretty detailed but the plastic is soft enough that the rifles and flag poles won't snap very easy, yet they're not so "bendy-wendy" that the pieces are poor quality. The poses are pretty cool, I think, especially the Cavalry. I think if you're the kind of gamer who likes to paint your game pieces, you'll probably like these, but you will need primer (see my comments on flags sticking below).The only bad thing are the flag stickers for the guidon bearers. The stickers themselves are good quality, but they don't stick to the plastic too well. My solution was to use some Lock Tite super glue. I placed a drop on the flag poles and slid the flags down (after folding) on the poles. Some of the flags still came loose after the first try. But after using a bit more glue, they seem to be holding well. Another note about the flags; I found the best way to fold them around the poles was to match up the opposite ends, stick them together, leave a gap to slide over the poles. I would recommend folding them first before gluing, if you decide to glue. This will likely minimize any mess.The rule book is actually quite thick, but the rules only cover only about 16 pages, most of which, is "air". You could probably condense the rules into about 6 or 7 pages. You do need to read them carefully though. While the rules are relatively simple, there are some subtle, yet very important details you can miss easily. However, once caught, they're pretty easy to commit to memory (like the use of the term "ordered units"). The rest is all battles/scenarios. It is a good quality glossy paper with lots O diagrams and illustrations.The game board and cardboard tokens are very good quality with sharp artwork. The game also comes with a tray at the bottom of the box to store all of your pieces in, sorted out nicely.The dice are great in that rather than having numbers or pips, they have symbols of the different unit types, flags and cross sabers. This simplifies the rules greatly as you only need to reference the dice to see what units your guys hit-no charts or conversions or anything like that. Even my 4 year old son was able to read them correctly. So, if you're looking to get your little ones into the awesome world of wargaming, this game would be a great start.First time wargamers will probably be very pleased with both the contents and the rules. Veteran wargamers might be a little disappointed at first as the game might seem very limited and it is. However, after playing the game a few times, I found that the board, while generic, can be made to fit almost any battlefield with the supplemental terrain pieces. Additionally, the wealth of starting scenarios will give most people quite a lot to start off with before the game becomes stale.All of my ratings were relative to other wargames. I gave the "fun" and "overall" rating five stars because of the entertainment potential for the largest possible audience. I also gave the "educational" value 5 stars because I think this would be a great way for the maximum amount of otherwise disinterested people to learn about "God Bless American History". 4 stars for durability-the cardboard, while good stock, is not laminated and if a 4 year old gets a hold of your pieces, you can say good bye to all of your flags and rifle barrels-the plastic isn't that "bendy-wendy".I would caution veteran wargamers not to expect too much. This doesn't seem to be designed for the grognards. I would rate the complexity of this game somewhat above the newer versions of Risk, but still as replayable as Axis and Allies. If you like your games complex like Third Reich or a screaming game of A&A-Global-1940-with-1-million-house-rules;, you probably won't care for this game. But, if you're  wargamer who's looking for something light, or someone who wants an entertaining, asthetically pleasing game for a couple hours in the afternoon, bust out the Sam Adams because you'll probably enjoy this game. Cheers!
summary: Great Afternoon Beer and Pretzel Game

reviewText: Bought this for my 13 year old for Christmas. He loves it. We didnt think the whole family would. His older brother and father play it quite a bit too. My 8 year old is learning it and it is easier for him than some games.
This is a great game. One of my favorite board games. Teaches you a lot. Only problem is the flag stickers, they don't stick well, but that is hardly comparable to the good things about this game.

My husband and I love this game. It is easy to play and you can set up the board following one of the battles listed in the manual that comes with it, or you can just wing it. We like to pick a battle, play, then read what the actual outcome of the battle was. Good way to get kids to take an interest in the Civil War.
Great game.  Everything was perfect.  We will definitely order more games like this in the future.  Thank you very much.

I have owned many Avalon Hill games in the past but have not played a game for some time. I found Battle Cry 150th a very well made game, all pieces were study and the artwork was great.The play has enough rules to make it somewhat realistic but is not to complicated for someone to play who is not a big wargamer. All in all it is a very fun game and gives a good background of the Civil War.I also have a comment for a previous commenter. You said that you had an extra Union Infantry piece, well the bags were sealed in the game I purchased but I was missing 1 Union Infantry piece. So I know where yours came from. I contacted Wizards.com and they are mailing me the missing piece this week. Great service from the distributer.

Battle Cry 150 is a great 2 player game. It has really nice pieces, cards and board (except for the flag stickers, which are difficult to work with)The game tries to make you understand what it feels like to command a large army. You play cards from your hand to send orders to you units and generals. There's never enough orders, and your best plans can fall apart right in front of you simply because your troops won't do what you need them to do. This system is called "commands and colors" and has spun off other games that cover various eras of warfare (from ancients all the way to WW2)Command, Control and Communications are the "Three Cs" of warfare that generals throughout the ages have had to contend with. It is a timeless issue. Battle Cry 150 teaches that lesson in a fast, fun, and challenging way. Two thumbs up!

I bought this game because the 150th Anniversary update included the Battle of Prairie Grove, where my Great-Great-Grandfather fought, and I was interested in "recreating" the battle to see what might, or might not, have happened "if". [For an excellent book on Prairie Grove, I recommendFields of Blood: The Prairie Grove Campaign (Civil War America).]Each battle scenario is mapped out for you in the instruction book, with terrain, building, and troop placements all specified. Each side is given a number of "Command Cards" and the instructions designate which player takes the first turn.Each side has Infantry, Cavalry, and Artillary - as well as Generals and flag bearers. The goal in each scenario is dictated by the rule book, and is based upon the 30 different Civil War Scenarios presented.The "Command Cards" determine whether the left flank, centre, or right flank is commanded - and how many units in that area are commanded. You can go from a mere "scouting" party, to a full frontal attack - if you have and use the right card. The need for a certain type of "Command Card" gives the game an unpredictability that is truly a part of warfare, as do the use of dice rolls to determine the outcome of particular engagements.I found the game both enjoyable and educational. I have learned a lot about strategy, tactics, consequences, and the various battles.I do find the rules a bit "weak" in some areas, and have modified a couple of them:1) The game allows that even if only 1 unit is present in a hex, it is still at "full strength" and can destroy four or more enemy units. I have modified this so that an army can defeat only the number of units it has present.2) The game does not allow you to split units which are together in one hex. This is unrealistic, as units were split all the time. I have made it so that I can send two units off in one direction, and two in another, if I so choose.3) The game does not allow you to combine units, so if you have only 1 unit left in one hex, and 1 unit left in another hex, they have to remain separated. In reality, this doesn't happen, as units often combined, and in the heat of combat, units often were completely mixed up with other units. I have modified this so that isolated units can combine.4) The game places all pieces who were involved in the battle on the gameboard at the start of the game, without regard for "when" they became involved. For instance, at Antietam, AP Hill did not arrive until mid-afternoon, but in the game, he is there from the beginning. I think it would be good to have some kind of "delay" of (in this case) 10 turns or so, to give account for Hill's late - and vital for the final outcome - appearance. Likewise at Prarie Grove, Union General Blunt arrived after the battle began, but in the game he is present from the start. A "delay" of 6-8 turns would help to make the game more "realistic".5) The game does not allow for divisions that were present, but not used. At Antietam, McClellan kept much of his cavalry in reserve, and, as such, they were not a major factor in the battle. They are not represented in the game. A good "what if" would be to have the cavalry become "available" after a few turns and see what difference they would have made at the "Burnside Bridge".These are personal "quibbles" and the rules are good as they are. If you want to introduce more "realistic" aspects, then modify the rules to suit yourself.As I said, I have enjoyed the game, and highly recommend it to you. Of course, having played the battle - or even before playing the battle, reading up on it to find out who, what, when - will make the game even more enjoyable.p.s. I ended up winning (for the South) the battle of Prairie Grove - but in the process I think that I killed my g-g-grandfather.
summary: Great game for re-enactment and "what if"

reviewText: Battle Cry is a two person Civil War game. I feel like it is somewhat of a cross between Risk and Settlers of Catan. The board is flat, and you place hex pieces to map out the battlefield with the appropriate terrain. Then, you place your pieces down. The rule book has a vast variety of different battles to choose from, and it maps out each one, telling you where to place terrain and troops. It also lets you know of any special rules for that scenario, how many cards you get, and who goes first. Setup time can be long, but oh, is it worth it.Like I said, it is sort of like a cross between Settlers and Risk. It is like Settlers because of the hex-pieces determining terrain. It is like Risk in that you have your troops move around dice to determine if you roll a hit or not. You are given a set number of cards at the beginning of the game, and those contain the command orders you may play. You draw a new card at the end of every turn. When you play a card, you give orders to the appropriate "units" and that activates them to move and battle. Once battle is over and you've drawn your card, it is the other person's turn.The goal of the game is to collect "flags" which are connected to units. As you kill off units, you get the last man standing who is holding a flag and that counts for one victory point. Each scenario has its own rules for how many flags it takes to win, but the typical number is six.Each game takes around an hour to play after setup is done, and I have played around three games now. I have lost two out of three...but I don't really care because of how much fun I was having. Seriously, I cannot recommend this game enough and I cannot wait to play more. :)

This is a great game that both my son and I enjoy very much.  We have played a different battle every night after dinner for the last week. I bought it five days ago.  We draw straws to figure out who plays which side and it normally takes about an hour or more but time goes by quickly. I am a high school math/science teacher and the one thing that I like is the analytic opportunity that is created by the game.  My son can look at things evaluate them and even today in one battle he said when looking at the board......"there is no high ground."  They were studying the Civil War in school which is why I initially bought the game.  If we play a game every night it should take me into the spring at which time he wants to get another board game like this.  I bought this game for him as an early Christmas present and when I asked him if he liked this gift , he said it was the best gift he every received. It is a great way of spending time with your kids.
This is an amazing game and I highly recommend it. The movable terrain tiles are super. In fact after doing the Civil war my grandson and I are using it for the revolutionary war figures as well

If you only play the provided scenarios with Battle Cry, that's fine. But what I truly love about this game is the ability to create your own. I'll research an obscure Civil War battle and learn everything about it. Then I create a scenario that I apply to the game and fight a simulation of the real thing. It's a great learning experience that results in some enjoyable game play. You combine strategy with luck to see who is victorious, and it's amazing how often the game parallels history. There are a few custom scenarios available that require two sets of the game (Shiloh, Antietam and Gettysburg) - and I know of one guy who sets up battles with four sets! I don't go quite that far, but who knows...? Great game, easy to learn, lots of variety, highly customizable. Totally recommended.
summary: Love the Versatility of this Game

reviewText: Little difference from the original. I actually like the vibrancy of this one. Fun and easy to learn. I plan on painting the figures to get more enjoyment out of it, otherwise it's blue and grey plastic. That's a bit much for most people to do. For me it will add to the ability to see them better. The game is awesome. I had the old one and my little boy took all the places to play "army" with them. Keep the box from your little boys.

This is a fun re-make of the original that most of us played as kids.  Since I am more of a traditional wargamer with the map and tiny unit counters a game like this strikes me as more of a toy.  Still, its a great little system for the novice, and even for the grognard wargamer like myself.Many people who might otherwise not get into strategy gaming because they are put off by the perceived complexity of wargames might get inspired to play this.  The cute blue and grey toy soldiers with flags are visually appealing.  The moveable terrain pieces makes for attractive, simple maps.Those who want a more detailed simulation with historical Brigades and Regiments won't find that here.  Units are generic according to type and can be any size depending on the action fought.  This gives the game a lot of flexibility, and allows for the players to design myriads of their own battles. But the historical detail is lacking a bit. Still, the 30 scenarios included in the game are more than enough to get your teeth into.  Many focus on lesser known actions of the Civil War which is always nice to see.A fun re-make for those who played the original long ago.  A much different game now.  A great idea for the novice gamer and for those who have only played regular board games before.  You can probably get your girl friend to play this one!  Fun also for the expereinced strategy gamer as the larger pieces are easier to move around than the small ones in wargames.  Fun over-all with cards adding a lot of variety and chance elements to the battles.  Great release for Civil War 150 anniversary!
I really enjoy playing this game.  Play all the missions with one opponent then switch sides.  Well worth the money!

When we first opened up the box we were a little overwhelmed, however after reading the manual we starred and haven't looked back. We were worried it would be to complex however it turned out to be a quick learning game. The various battles make the game something you can play over and over and not get bored. Only problem was the flags, they didn't stick well but I just added a little super glue on each and haven't had any problems since. Great game!

Very fun game. Makes for a good combination of luck and strategy. The pieces look great, the board is sweet, and the box has neat compartments to keep all your pieces organized. One of the best things about this board game compared to other strategy games is how quickly a round will play. One round should def not last more than an hour once you have figured out the rules. On that note, the rules are VERY easy to understand. The only complaint I have would be that the terrain pieces are pretty easy to slide out of place. But this is a very small concern. As long as you keep a steady hand when you're moving units to and from, its no big deal. I've though of solutions the manufacturer could have made to fix this problem but all of them would raise the price and ruin the aesthetics. ANYWAY, def worth every dollar. Tremendous replay value.I should include this to anyone buying this game. I had trouble with this because the definition of an order could have been better explained. I had to go online to figure out how attacking applies to an order. Me and my friend were making the mistake of attacking with every unit on the board capable of attacking during the attack phase which, frustratingly is what the rule book tells you to do. But what you're supposed to do is only attack with ORDERED units. So lets say you got a card which gives you three orders in the right flank. You can make three units move of course. But lets say you wanted one of those units to attack but not move. Well you need to specify which three units are being ordered from the start. So first specify the three units, move two, then attack with the one not moving during the attack phase (and attack with the other moved units if capable). It's very simple but I don't think the book explained it well enough. Though the original way we played the game made it go pretty quick and fun :)

This is a wonderful board game that is fun, challenging and does not take an entire day (or week) to play. The board and pieces are nice looking and the scenarios for the different Civil War battles are varied enough to teach the importance and impact of terrain, troop disposition, artillery, coordinated movements, etc...  Movements in the game are limited by the cards you draw, but there's still a strong element of skill involved.I play this all the time with my nine year old son and we love it.  I love that it takes an hour to play.  When we go away from home for a trip, this is the one game we always bring.
summary: A great game that won't take 8 hours to play

reviewText: Very nice product.  I am sorry that this gaming system didn't last long, but by itself it is totally worth it.

While I'm well aware that the original Battle Cry predates Memoir '44, I played the latter first and so buying this game was a matter of wanting a very similar game just with slightly different rules and a different setting.  In that regard, I was not disappointed.Battle Cry is what is commonly called a 'light wargame'.  The game comes with multiple scenarios, each one based off of historical battles from the Civil War.  Thanks to the different terrain tiles, each battle presents its own set of advantages, disadvantages and challenges for each side.  This means that the game has a fairly high replay value, which is good for something that costs nearly fifty dollars.  Another thing I like about the game is that a single battle is usually finished within an hour.  Although some people might find this a disadvantage, I've found that my shelf has far too many games that, while fun, are almost never used because finding an entire afternoon to devote to them is difficult.Of course, the game is not without its flaws.  The rules are fairly simple and easy to grasp, but this does reduce the amount of strategic options.  Furthermore, while the commands and colors system is usually excellent, it can at times be frustrating when the battle boils down to who had the right cards at the right time.  Being the first game to utilize the system, it lacks some of the depth that Memoir '44 has.  That being said, I am still a huge fan of the game and am happy to have it as part of my collection.

The booster pack arrived completely sealed. If you have ordered a booster box before, then you know what you are getting. For those that haven't, it is a box of 36 packs of 15 cards. The set seems to be one that lacking in overall variety, but the quality of the set is solid. I am glad I bought this.

My Grandson asked for game assets for his birthday.I sent him this pack and he was delighted.This 'full pack' is great for someone [like my grandson] who is really into the game.But this is more than you need to give to a Newbie who is testing the game environment.Uhh ... talking about this stuff with the gamer that you know can enhance relationships.

Plenty of fun cards to be had in this set.  If you're looking at this for a gift and your child/friend plays Magic a lot, this is a great set to get.  If they're just beginning, I would suggest getting theMagic The Gathering M11 Core Set 2011 SEALED Booster Boxor M12 set when it comes out in July as the cards are a bit easier for beginners to build decks with.  My MBS box came from a third party seller in pristine condition.
summary: Good first expansion to Scars of Mirrodin

reviewText: Having played both Dungeons & Dragons and Axis & Allies most of my life, I think I was the target audience for this game. The game system is basically Axis & Allies, but tweaked for the D&D fantasy setting. There are lots of dice, event cards for each nation that give them a different feel, lots of cool miniatures (each nation has different miniatures for the same type of unit; for the foot soldiers, Karkoth has skeleton warriors, Vailin has elven archers, the Iron Circle has hobgoblins, and Nerath has human soldiers), "dungeons" to explore (to give it more of a D&D feel), and a beautiful map board. For a game of this type, it also plays fairly quickly; the average game should last about 2 to 3 hours. All in all, a very worthwhile purchase.
summary: A game that is a lot of fun

reviewText: this is a really fun board game if you like risk and dungeon dragons you will like this game. very fun game to play

If you're either a risk, D&D, or Axis n Allies fan like me, you will love this game. Great miniatures, easy to learn rules, that still maintain depth, and true to D&D fashion, there's room in the rulebook for you to add your own house rules like I have.
Fun game, little on the long side with set up but once set none stop fun.  Miniatures and dice what more can you want?

Conquest of Nerath at first looks like a broken game. Its asymetrical map, radically different factions and over-price and under-priced units look like a child's version of a game that they made so that they can win. But as the game progresses, the game is so brilliantly balanced without the feeling that everyone is the same, that it makes for a unique strategic game.The game has 4 factions made into 2 alliances (you can but don't have to play the alliances). The biggest bad guys go first and completely decimate the map in one round. They start with more property, earn more initial income and have more and stronger starting armies. But they have less starting gold (by one or two or three gold pieces) and have weaker event cards. The rag-tag left overs will find themselves struggling for a foothold for the next round or two. But as the dust settles and with some keen strategic maneuvers, it's anyone's game.Each faction has its own flavor. The Iron Circle will draw cards that might indicate that they enforce compulsoray military service, so you get bonus hobgoblin soldiers. The elves may draw an event card that enables their elven archers to move double the speed with their quick elven legs. The super-evil black-death faction may draw a spell that makes their black dragon have extra acidic breath. And so forth. The cards are quite varied as they alter and flavor the game with each passing round.Fighters and wizards will go off on quests to defeat ogres, dragons and basilisks and the like to earn powerful treasures that will make your entire nation stronger -- or just your heroes. These treasures will open up new strategic avenues for your nation.Or your fighters and wizard can join the armies.Meanwhile, your armies will defend and expand your borders, sail the seas to gain an island property, and establish castles from which they can build more armies on the front lines.Each unit of your army has a certain percent chance to damage another unit. And most of them have other special abilities (for instance, the dragon can ignore some damage and fly, the storm elemental doubles in strength over water and the wizard can kill others before the first shot is even fired). You will be constantly organizing your army to make it the most efficient.The entire game is made up of high quality materials. The figures are all strong and simply don't break under normal use. The box's art and appearance is top-notch and durable. But the part I like most is the interior. The box has everything laid out beautifully. It has a spot for all of your tokens, cards and units. There's no need to get zip-lock bags to organize everything yourself (although, I did use zip-lock bags in order to separate out the types of units for quick set-up).After playing a few games, I can set-up the game in 20 minutes by myself. I can break it down in 15 minutes on my own. Each full round (each player gets to go once) takes about 30-45 minutes. A short game can be completely in 3 full rounds, which takes about 2 hours for me.The rules aren't too thick. There's quite a few exceptions to remember, but it all makes logical sense. I had the rules down pat and memorized after just a few rounds of play.If anything was lacking, I'd buy a booster back with more treasure variation, more event variation and more dungeon variation if such a booster pack was available. I was also hoping for more dungeoneering mechanics and hero leveling. As it is, each dungeon just has 1 level with 1 or 2 monsters in it and the heroes don't level. I might just write my own rules to flavor the game for that.If you like strategy games and fantasy and you've got a group of friends to play with, this one is an awesome buy.
summary: Unique and exciting board game experience

reviewText: Pick your army and battle your enemies, explore dungeons, and expand your empire.  The new Dungeons & Dragons board game "Conquest of Nerath" is a delight for gamers everywhere.  It plays like an interesting variation of Risk with a D&D; twist; while world domination isn't the only way to win the game, building armies and defeating opponents is the core of game play.  Two to four people can play, but due to the way the game is set up, having four players is definitely ideal; all four armies must be in play, so a two-person game requires each player to play two armies at once.  The quality of the game pieces is impressive, from the sturdy Event and Treasure cards to the glossy playing board to the relatively detailed individual army pieces, and experienced gamers will appreciate not having to separate those pieces from their original sprues.  The overall design and layout is reminiscent of  Fourth Edition D&D; player handbooks.  With its extensive rule book, "Conquest of Nerath" may seem daunting at first, but once players get the hang of game play, it is easy to get lost in this strategic board game.Originally published for San Francisco/Sacramento Book Reviews.
summary: Explore dungeons, defeat your opponents, and conquer the world!

reviewText: If you like Axis and Allies, you'll enjoy this game. It takes a little while to setup and longer to play but we had a lot of fun doing it. There are plenty of special touches to the game that make it uniquely DnD while at the same time making it interesting for anyone not particularly interested in that genre.The quality of the game pieces was excellent and the box has without a doubt the best organizer for those numerous pieces I've ever seen. You won't be disappointed.

I've always been a huge risk fan, but the length of time to play it and the simplicity of the game's mechanics eventually grew a little stale. Thankfully this game fixes every problem one could have with Risk.The races all have the same units though they look different from each other. The 4 playable races do have different decks of cards though and different starting positions so they all play and feel different though. Each of the units in the game roll different attack dice and have several differing abilities too so it's always fun recruiting and battling.The game also uses a Victory Point system that you can preset per game to keep the length to what ever you'd like as well as encouraging players to play offensively instead of just turtleing in.If you've ever even been slightly interested in Risk this game is the perfect updated and more fun successor.

Conquest of Nerath is a fantastic boardgame! Each of the game's powers have interesting minatures, and the box is wonderfully organized (so you can keep each power's pieces separate and ease their storage after play). That said, my nephews loved it and are looking forward to play the game again.

I was introduced to this board game by a group of friends. I'm a board and card game aficionado, and love rich mechanics that aren't too convoluted. Nerath strikes an even balance between being complicated, straightforward, and interesting. There is no clear dominant strategy; the event cards will mix up the game every time. I've played eight games so far, and not a single game has looked remotely similar. The victory point method of determining the winner is good, but so far I've favored the longer games, where the goal is to take both enemy capitals; some weird tactics come into play with victory point games, which is just fine, but something about marching across the landscape with vast armies appeals to me. There are a lot of ways to play the game, though, and the four nations are very asymmetrical, which makes for an interesting play experience. You'll probably develop favorites; I'm partial to the under-dog starting positions, so I tend toward the Iron Circle and League of Nerath, but I've really enjoyed games as all four sides. The default Alliance mode of play is interesting, and sets up conflict right away. Conflict in the game starts up immediately, and it never really lets up.My complaints with the game are minor. I have seen a tendency for one nation to get ganged up on, which is not necessarily a bad thing as long as the freed up nation either comes to the defense of their beleaguered ally or takes advantage of their deficient attentions. Luckily, playing toward a strong comeback is very possible, and one of the more exciting positions to be in.I really adore this game, and have introduced it to a great many of my friends. I strongly suggest picking this one up if you like strategy games with longevity!
summary: Phenomenal board game with considerable replayability.

reviewText: I have not played it very many times but overall it was a pretty good game.  A bit like the old game Samurai Swords or Shogun.  I think they are now calling it Ikusa but with a fantasy theme instead of Feudal Japan.  It seems like there may be a bit of a limitation in the game, however, when playing with three players.  Like I said I have not played extensively but the three player option we tried was for one player to play two of the four faction.  This might be fine for people who have played the game extensively but it seemed like a bit much for three new players.  So that while it says the game is playable by 2, 3 or 4 players it is really best played with 4 and the 2 and 3 player option is really best left to more experience players of the game.

While I've rated this board game two stars, it's not to say that it's an awful board game (or I would have given it 1 star, but 3 stars means the game would have been ok and I'll explain in a bit why it's not).Now this game functions as a war game and you get four armies on the board. This game markets itself for 2-4 players, but anything less than four players will force you to use rules that tried to find a way to make it work. Two players and four players are the real options, 3 players won't work so well as the rules for doing so can be a strain.Pros:1. This game incorporates the use of points so that the game doesn't drag out like risk can.2. This game has different units that move differently and have different rules to how they work.3. Dungeons offer the feel like you're fighting for treasure, even though the actual dungeon system is lame.4. Event cards offer flavor to the factions on the map.5. Tactics have a strong role in this board game.Cons:1. Different units move at different speeds and you can lose track of how much they can move, in addition to costing differently so you always need the reference sheet on hand in addition to different attack dice for different unit types. Movement also has additional rules attached, that while they feel realistic (dragons can fly over enemy territory without engaging but must land on friendly soil), can be a pain to remember (for instance, landing on enemy land that has no units AFTER a combat round is impossible as it would start combat and you can't do that once combat is over hence even though the land is empty, you can't land there).2. The dungeon system is REALLY lame, you pull at random a 'creature', which has very little development to it that you can actually simplify a description of said creature as 'strong/weak' and that's it. No real flavor to the point that it feels like the whole dungeon system was unnecessary.3. Only two hero units (hero units are the only ones able to fight in dungeons), with wizard easily outclassing the fighter because of the overpowered system of 'first strike', meaning before you check to see if the enemy has harmed/killed your troops, you check to see if you had enough successes with first strike to have gone ahead and won the battle. The fighter's SLIGHTLY cheaper cost does not offset this advantage.4. Overly complicated battle rules, especially for naval battles. First, only hero units can attack at sea while on a boat, second, elemental units do two times the damage at sea, third, sticking units on a boat spends one movement point for a boat, four, both armies roll attack at the same time and damage occurs at the same time meaning both can wipe each other out (never encountered this concept before, and remembering it amidst the many other rules is a pain), five, siege engines that are ATTACKING do more damage than siege engines that are defending (no wait, I meant POTENTIALLY, they roll two attacks and even though logic dictates that either both hit or both fail, it's somehow possible to miss on one, it's one of those rules that are more for mechanics than to actually make sense), six, building a castle confers no benefits to units, only to act as a point to drop off reinforcements, seven, some units can move again after a battle. There are other complicated battle rules but I'll stop here.5. Event cards offer the ONLY flavor to the factions on the map. The different factions have no real defining trait except for event cards, and most event cards are extremely similar. Would have been better to either work harder on defining the different factions or simply make them all the same.Truth be told? For what it achieves, I'd rather get risk. I don't know how I sound saying that, but just try to understand when I say 'for what it achieves'. If this game could feel more unique to its take on war games, then I'd prefer it to risk. If I had to sum up the game in a few words?'An unnecessarily complicated version of risk'Again, it's not that it's not fun, it's just that for what it achieves I'd rather get risk.
summary: Less than risk but better than nothing

reviewText: It's not bad, but its not really that great. The mini's are pretty basic and not very detailed. They are also really BIG. The game is all based on the cards that represent the mini's on the board. The game play is ok, even with the advanced rules. I played wings of war and that actually plays much better. Anyway I'm not going to really rag on the game but its not as good as I was hoping and I really would have liked it better, even with the game play if the Mini's work cooler.

Conquest of Nerath _does_ borrow from RISK in the sense that is a territorial control game involving a lot of little miniature "troops" but beyond that it's pretty different. A set number of victory points to win guarantees a quick game if so desired, which can be adjusted for the number of players and the desired length of the game. There are cards that each player uses which are great in changing up everything at a moments notice making sure that even underdogs and pull off a victory. Each unit uses different sized die to attack, there are dungeons to explore as a kind o "player vs. the game" aspect which yeild powerful treasure to help your army.There's a lot of meat to this game, anyone who enjoys a good war/strategy game will love CoN even if they aren't a D&D; junkie. The only small gripes I can give the game is that setup can take a bit (there's a lot of pieces) and the dragon units seem extremely overpowered. Easily fixed wit a house rule to cap how many your army can control. I have a full review of the game over on my blog if anyone cares to take a closer look before they buy.[...]
summary: Like RISK with a strong fantasy twist. Also unlike RISK, actually fun and not terrible.

reviewText: I used to play AAM and WAS, so I decided to give this game a shot. Overall, the rules a simple and fun, the models are very nice and the variety of them is reasonable. The starter set really does include everything you need for a fun game. The scale of the miniatures is huge, which may annoy some people, but I love the detail. This really is a small scale game on the whole, though, usually a battle involves 2 or 3 aircraft on each side.
Awesome Game!  We have run 3 sessions so far.  Lots of suspense, fun, and realistic feel to the wheeling, diving, climbing plans fighting for positions.  Highly recommended.

This game lets everyone play. I am not the biggest D&D nerd but i'm up in the ranks. I usually run the games with friends of mine that i think only play to humor me. this game lets everyone get a piece of the action of player and DM. there is very little set up time and the rules are easy to follow. You can play the game with JUST the stuff it comes with and if you are a veteran DM you can really spice it up by applying the rules from the full version of 4ed. The replay-ability is awesome and you can even play alone (as most of us veterans often do:) you get the adventure with the ease of a regular board game. Gets even the most uninterested players (my sister-in-law) into the game.
summary: Loved this game, great for people who have never played

reviewText: Annoying. The shipping not only took weeks, but apparently the company couldn't even afford a box and my game was smashed into a padded mailing envelope that had to be cut and taped back together because it wasn't big enough to hold the box.  The box was smashed and two of the pieces were missing... luckily, I found them -- they had fallen out into the padded mailer.Great game. Buy it from someone else.
summary: Great Game - Buy it from someone else!

reviewText: I didn't really want to review Conquest of Nerath.It's not that I don't like board games, but that I just don't have as much time to play them - my Xbox 360, Playstation 3, Tivo, and D20 Modern tabletop role-playing games all compete for time on my calendar. But then Wizards of the Coast offered me a chance to playtest Conquest of Nerath and I just couldn't say no.Conquest of Nerath is a Risk-like tabletop strategy game that involves moving armies across territories.  Reminiscent of the Might & Magic games, Conquest of Nerath has two scales: army and hero scale.  Armies, which range from creatures to castles, soldiers to ships, can only play across the terrain. Heroes, which include fighters and wizards, are an asset to an army and can also go dungeon crawling - which, let's face it, is the whole point of playing a D&D-themed; version of Risk.I've been railing against the decoupling of Dungeons & Dragons from toy stores for over a decade now, and it's refreshing to see Wizards of the Coast finally get it. Conquest of Nerath is not just D&D; in name alone.  It has a format and layout similar to 4thEdition Dungeons & Dragons, the terrain pieces are littered with familiar places like the Temple of Elemental Evil and the Tomb of Horrors, and the four different dragons actually look like their tabletop role-playing game counterparts.  Conquest of Nerath is proud of its roots and it harkens back to the original Dungeons & Dragons set in utilizing heroes on the battlefield.There are also several stylistic flourishes that appeals to veteran role-players.  Gaming grognards will recognize the aforementioned staples of dungeon crawling but also have a weakness for dice (guilty!). The number of dice determines a monster's hits, and you inflict one hit by rolling above a 6 on various dice.  Dragons, in case you're wondering, roll a d20. Conquest of Nerath comes with a lot of dice, but be warned - you will not have enough.  But then again, if you're anything like me, you have plenty of dice within each reach, if not stuck in your couch somewhere. If you like dice, you're going to love Conquest of Nerath.As a matter of necessity, the four armies of plastic pieces that come with the set are not 25mm scale.  They're probably more appropriate to a 15mm scale, although some are not necessarily scale-specific.  Ogres could easily pass as goblins, treants could easily pass as...smaller treants.  For those looking for repaints, this set won't provide much fodder unless you plan to use the smaller scale, in which case $80 buys you four armies.There are also event cards that mix up the game as well as treasure cards earned from dungeon crawling. If the game's gorgeous design falls somewhat flat, it's on the cards, which lack pictures.  If I win a vorpal sword after battling a medusa, I want to see it!Speaking of medusa, wizards and certain monsters have a first strike ability.  Normally all damage is inflicted simultaneously, which ensures mutual destruction.  But wizards have the ability to attack first before the opponent inflicts damage.  They also can dungeon crawl.  Although the damage they inflict is smaller, first strike is a very powerful ability and I ended up hording wizards as quickly as I could.If Conquest of Nerath has a flaw it's the fiddly bits: pieces for the dungeons, which could just as easily have been cards; treasury tokens that could easily be handled by counters; and victory points that could also have been handled by counters.  I prefer less pieces, but then again I may be biased by my mobile one-year-old's propensity to eat anything she can catch.Conquest of Nerath is a long overdue game that bridges the gap between tabletop dungeon crawls and board games. It's about time D&D; got a decent shot at the mainstream game audience.  Now all we need are conversion rules to integrate the Conquest of Nerath into mass combat rules for tabletop play!You can learn more about Conquest of Nerath at Wizard of the Coast's web site.

If you are an RPG player of D&D who loves story and creativity that Role-playing brings, look else where. If you are interesting in a solid boardgame system with a nice setting, good production quality and overall fun play for kids - this dungeon crawl is worth it.
For someone new/getting into D&D, this was a great lead into the old school pencil and paper game. It really convinced several of us to give the real thing a shot.
I really like this game! The only problem is the setup time which can be a tedious task. But overall, is a great board game!

I am a huge Drizzt fan and have been eargerly awaiting the arrival of this game.  I love it. The minatures are awesome.  The monster selection is significantly better than castle ravenloft.  I have played 3 adventures so far.  Drizzt's character is awesome.
summary: This Game Is everything I hoped it would be.

reviewText: Well, this is an awesome D&D dungeon crawling board game.  I think being that it's D&D says enough.  This was designed well and plays well.  One of the best dungeon crawler board games out there along with Descent 2.0 and Castle Ravenloft, Wrath of Ashardalon.  The components are top notch and the hero variety is good.

I am a avid World War II miniatures collector, and thus have many Axis and Allies sets, including their ground warfare soldiers and vehicles and the War at Sea line. I have been looking intently toward getting involved into WWII air warfare. I already have the Wings of War game, including sets of those miniatures.As a comparison:Pros:- Angels 20 miniatures are 1/100 scale, and much larger than WoW. They are easier to handle, and more durable.- The Angels 20 system is a better value, for the starter and the boosters.- The system allows for many types of planes, with more variability and special abilities. The starter includes cards for all 31 planes of the initial set.- The use of hexes removes the need for movement aids. In WoW, you need a special card deck for each aircraft, which is interesting, but is sometimes a pain to use.- Angels 20 includes advantages for pilot quality.- Angels 20 provides much more flexibility to perform maneuvers, and operations at different speeds.Cons:- Angels 20 miniatures are not painted as well as the WoW miniatures. Although smaller, the WoW miniatures have high detail and quality.- The damage system of Angels 20 is comparable to other A&A; miniatures games, and is thus quite simplistic. The damage and outcomes are portrayed more realistically in WoW. Pilots can be injured, you may have fire, smoke, rudder damage, etc.- Angels 20 requires a large hex map, included in the starter. WoW does not need a map.- Just like other Axis and Allies games, you need lots of dice, and there many dice modifiers and special abilities to count and add up. WoW is diceless, using simultaneous movement and firing, and damage chits drawn in the blind. Angels 20 uses sequential movement and firing. This may be neither a con or a pro, depending on your opinion.Overall, I enjoy both games, but I am much more likely to continue collecting the Axis and Allies miniatures planes.
summary: Nice set of WWII fighter airplanes. Very good game system.

reviewText: I good strategy game that scales well for beginners and advanced players alike.  Lots of different game variations allow for numerous replays, and the game easily adapts to home rule adjustments to suit your playing needs.Pieces are plastic but durable, game board pieces are thick and made to last.  The cards are a little thin and have warped some but it doesn't detract from game play.

I was lucky enough to snag this off Amazon for $37.Just getting back into D&D.;  Only playing 1st edition this was a big change.  It took a few rounds but it was very easy to catch on to the game play.  It was nice that a DM is not needed.  Every one gets to play.  The game comes with a 10 good scenarios that can be played out in about 2 hours.  Some were so good we played them again and just switched up characters.  The game comes with a nice selection of miniatures.  You get your money back on those alone.  The map system is interlocking squares that you put together at random.  So every time you play its a new map.  Also great for building your own maps.My only negative about this is some characters just seem a bit over powered.  With some of the treasure items there is only a 1 in 10 chance of missing your target.After playing this I kept my eyes out for Wrath of Ashardalon, and Castle Ravenloft.  I have played some Wrath and wished I had started with that one first.  All 3  can be mixed together if you choose.  I plan to use them in future regular D&D; adventures and cant wait to make some of my own custom maps using the peaces that came with them.

the game is fun enough. the miniatures alone are worth the price of this box. 1 issue I have though not a big one is, out of the 9 times my buddies and I played this game we won only once, and barely.  my major issue with this was the condition the box arrived.  mine was crushed on one corner and had a puncture mark on the top. this package came from amazon, so department was tempered by surprise. the pieces were all fine so I never did anything about it.  the actual punch out pieces are delicate, be very careful punching then out.

...is simply amazing. I've played Wrath of Ashardalon and Castle Ravenloft. Ravenloft kicks your butt to the max. Ashardalon makes you work for it and sometimes kicks your butt. Drizzt makes you feel like you're the freakin hero and with some strategizing it is relatively easy but still VERY fun.If you've read the books you'll appreciate this game even more.

Best of the 3 D&D Board Games overall, though if you know the other games you're not going to be blown away.  It just adds some different tile features, has some mildly improved art additions, more diverse scenarios and play options, and more powerful heroes.  The true value of this game is for fans of the books - playing as the Companions of the Hall beats anonymous heroes in most cases.  Good value for the amount of game you get and the quality and quantity of the components, and the D&D series offers a game system that makes it easy to create your own scenarios.  Also a great challenge for miniature painters with 42 unpainted minis!
summary: Solid game system, excellent quality, good value.

reviewText: This is a great purely cooperative game.  Everyone plays a hero.  The monsters and encounters are designed so there is no one player who has to run all the bad guys.
summary: Miniture game with out an evil overlord

reviewText: I have found that the miniatures in this set can be easily primed and painted.Considering how expensive miniatures have gotten in past years getting them for less than a buck per miniature was a pretty good deal.  Some of the miniatures had much better detail than others but overall I was impressed.The game itself is a decent board game.The box is excellent sturdy material and keeps everything packed away neatly.
summary: Excellent way to get an assortment of miniatures.

reviewText: This is my first full episode of D&D (upgraded from the training wheels version) and my 9 y/o son and I are still learning the rules but we have lot of fun playing it.  Good family time.
what can you say its the best out there it did what i thought it was going to do I liked it I play this one almost the most out of all my games

This is my first foray into any of the D&D; Board games, so I had know idea what to expect.  First the game box is huge and heavy, there are a TON of components in there and to be honest it was a bit overwhelming at first.  After getting all the card stock items punched out and grouped it wasn't too bad.As far as the learning curve goes, me and 2 others finished up our first game without a ton of problems.  Sure we made some overall mistakes and had to to a lot of referencing the rulebook, but overall I was quite happy with how fast we learned the mechanics of the game system.  Basically, if you follow the directions and leave some time, the game isn't too hard to figure out.  Our first 3 man adventure "Search for Mithral Hall" took about 2 1/2 hours.The game was fun and we all enjoyed learning how to play the game.  Everyone is looking forward to the next round so I guess it was a success.Highly Recommended.
summary: Fun game, quality components, a good purchase.

reviewText: I played for the first time with my husband last night, and it was simple enough to pick up and learn (we didn't do the advanced play)We fudged some of the rules just because we forgot about some of the steps, but we beat the game and had a great time together.We've never played any D&D; besides Three Dragon Ante and the video games, but my husband has read some of the books.I liked the character choices and the enemies were interetesting. It was challenging but not so much that we didn't want to keep playing.

Great for getting people who are not so great at role playing into D&D.; Me and my friends are just those people; we like D&D; but have all found it hard to get into games because we're weak at role playing. It's especially nice not to need a GM since none of us are very qualified story tellers.Just like the other two D&D; board games (Castle Ravenloft and Wrath of Ashardalon) the rules and over all game play are simple enough to just jump in and play, but it still has enough to it that it retains much of the feel of a pen and paper D&D; game. There's still a lot of table talk, teamwork, and player interaction. And for those who are good at role playing, there's still room for it.So far I like the character selection, but if you really want a mage/wizard character, you wont find one in this game. All the player characters are physical fighters (Barbarian, Rogue, Archer, Fighter, etc.), so no magic.Otherwise, I like the setting, monster types, and villains. It's not all that different from Castle Ravenloft, which I've also played, though.
summary: Less role-playing, but just as much fun

reviewText: BASIC DESCRIPTION-----------------This is the 3rd version of the Dungeons and Dragons games. The other two are here:Dungeons and Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board GameWrath of Ashardalon: A D&D; BoardgameIf you've played any of those games, skip past this part and go right to THE GOOD.It plays the same and the parts are all interchangeable.The basic game is played similar to Dungeons and Dragons 4th edition. You move a character, you attack baddies using class-specific skills and you finish a map by getting a unique item or killing a certain creature.The rules make for a fun, quick game. After just two or three hours, you'll have finished a dungeon. This is awesome for players who don't have the time to invest into full-on roleplaying.You can play this game by yourself or with up to 5 people. The more the merrier. You can play by yourself because the enemies all have their artificial intelligence listed on a card. For instance, you might get a card that says something like:If this creature is more than 2 tiles away, it moves 2 tiles closerIf this creature is 2 tiles away or less, it shoots with an Attack +5, 1 damageIf this creature is adjacent to a hero, it uses a dagger with an Attack +2, 1 damageAttacks are rolled with a 20-sided die (the only die needed for the game -- it is included). If the 20-sided-die roll + the Attack >= the hero's AC, then it's a hit. So you'd want to engage the creature adjacent to it so that it will have a low chance of hitting your character.If you kill a creature, you gain a treasure and experience. If you ever roll a 20, you can trade experience to level up your character (can only be done once). A leveled up character has better stats and can have more skills.Now onto the good parts and bad parts of this game:THE GOOD--------The figures are the best yet. You get a bunch of goblins and undead along with some awesome trolls, a dragon and a massiveBalor. They are not painted like the expensive miniatures, but you could paint them yourself if you wanted. They are very durable and extremely well-detailed.Also, the quests in this edition are better than the others. They feel more personal. You get to know the characters better (they are R.A. Salvatore's already well-establish characters (note:  I have not read his Drizzt stuff yet, so you still get to know the characters even if you haven't read his work)). The game feels more connected and less "go here, kill this guy, move on."THE LESS GOOD-------------The previous 2 games had more solid cards. They were indisputably clear. Not so in this edition.During the 2nd or 3rd quest, we ran into a boss character's AI that was not clear. It said something similar to:  "If he is adjacent to only 1 hero, he attacks with a vampiric dagger. If he is more than 1 tile away, he approaches and attacks with a sword. If he is 2 tiles or more away, he moves 2 tiles closer."What wasn't clear was what he would do if he was adjacent to more than 1 hero. He isn't more than 1 tile away, but he has more than 1 hero adjacent to him. Does he use the sword? Does he use the dagger? Is he scared and doesn't do anything? (that's what the goblin archers do -- it's not a ridiculous thought)The next quest we did, we had to kill a dragon. The dragon's AI did some weird things. You had to be on his tile to attack him. But there were areas where you could be adjacent to the dragon, the dragon couldn't go by you and you couldn't attack the dragon.As far as we could tell, the card didn't list if the dragon could fly over characters (we assumed it could). It didn't list what the dragon would do if there was no place for it to land (would it toss the characters aside so that it had room? -- we assumed it would).It's not a major problem because everyong playing the game can just decide how to fill in the gaps. But it was somewhat annoying considering how perfect the AI was in the previous two games.OVERALL-------If you like dungeon hack-n-slash style of board games but don't want to invest the time that mammoth games likeDescent Journeys in the Darkrequire, then this is where you need to go.These are my favorite hack-n-slash board games I've ever played.
summary: Better and worse than previous like games

reviewText: Let me remind people before they start playing this. This game is hard in that things mainly don't go your way in the first place or frankly the whole game. But it's fun as hell getting owned though!

This game improves upon its predecessors (Ravenloft and Ashardalon games) by adding the stance mechanic, competitive cooperative team or player vs player scenarios. It does remove the campaign mode but there is plenty of official and unofficial content online as well as the ability to create your own adventure.Those familiar with the Drizzt books will recognize some of the scenario stories in the game but it is not necessary to know the story to enjoy this game. Definitely recommend if you enjoyed the previous games or just want to try the D&D; board games for the first time. There is a mix of luck (random card draws, tile draws, and dice rolls) but there is also a bit of tactical and teamwork play to help balance it out as well.
summary: Fans of the previous 2 D&D Board games or Drizzt books will like this

reviewText: This is a great game for beginners or those looking for DnD fun without having to prepare a game session. It plays like 4th edition lite and most adventures can be played in under 2 hours once you get the hang of the rules and setup. I also have the Castle Ravenloft game set which is a good purchase as well and Wrath of Ashardalon is currently in transit to me. Just keep in mind this is mostly a combat and trap oriented game. There is little to no role playing involved.
