She was thrilled to see her story published in an actual book. The quality of the book is excellent. In my daughter's word, "Look mommy, it looks like an actual book from the library!" My favorite part was the about the author section at the end. My daughter took her finished book to school and her classmates and teacher were dying to know how she made it. I love this product because it gets children excited and passionate about writing. The only draw back is the fact that there is a limit to the amount of words you can write on each page.

I picked up one of these for my three children, ages 5,7 and 9. While the older two have yet to really finish anything, the youngest was very eager to get started on the project. I chalk this up more to their personalities rather than how age appropriate the product is.I sat with him and made sure he adhered to the guidelines, which I would recommend. There are limits to the number of words each page can have. So it helps to sort work as an editor to the process in order to keep everything flowing smoothly.Once we were done and sent it out, he checked the mail constantly. It arrived within a few weeks, and we were both really excited to hold a copy of the book in our hands. It's a durable, hardcover book. And I think it gave a real sense of accomplishment for him to have made this PRODUCT, this thing that you could hold onto and show people. His "what I want to be when I grow up" became an author. He would frequently relate this to his teacher and grandparents. I think it gives a real connection to the creative process, and we both really enjoyed working on it together.I will say that the only, brief and fleeting moment of disappointment for him was when he realized the pictures in the book were his, and not some professional rendering of what he'd drawn. I had no idea he'd expected this, and quickly allayed the disappointment by telling him how great it was that he'd done it all himself. Totally fine after that.This was a great experience for both of us. I plan on sending one to my niece for her 5th birthday.

I bought for my nephew's birthday...he's 4 years old.  I loved the idea of giving him the ability to write his own book, illustrate it, and then to be able to have a real one made was just cool.  Initially, the concept was a tad lost on him, but he soon understood.  Once he understood he was really excited.  A cool little present but it also a present that the parents or another adult will have to help with....it an activity...a memory.  I have not seen the finished book as of yet but will update when I do.

This has been my daughter's favorite gift of all time.  She drew all the pictures, then dictated the story to me.  Her face, when we received a hard-bound real book in the mail was priceless!  I'd like to do one of these every year.  You can't pick a better gift than this one.
last year my 6yr old daughter got one and she got it again this year for Christmas. she likes it. she is working on her 2nd book now. I can not wait to see it "published"!

I helped my son create his book when he was 5. Now that he's 11 it's such a treasure to have. Everytime we pick it up to read it, I can recall the time was spent together creating his story. I highly recommend this.
This is great for those creative stories that your children write. The story can be illustrated and will be a lasting keepsake for your family.  I highly recommend this.

I love the idea of this product and the quality of its results. I purchased this product for my now 23 year old daughter and it is an absolute treasure to pick her book up now and read who her friends were when she was young as well as what her thoughts and dreams were 16 years ago! She can see who she was herself when she was little, in her own words, as well as see what kind of artist she was so many years ago.  I have an 8 year old daughter who did her own book last year and she loves to read her own story over and over again.  I'm sure she will treasure it just as much as my oldest daughter 15 years from now. My youngest is turning 7 this November and I plan on purchasing another kit for her to complete the cycle and continue our tradition. It is amazing to see the positive reactions from my kids when they look at what they did on their own (with a little help from Mom). I have also purchased this product for my many neice's and nephew's.  I think it is an absolute necessity to be able to capture your little ones innocence and for them to be able to look back on how much they have grown and changed over the years.  I will continue to purchase this product again and again and share what I feel is a true gem!

We were gifted this illuStory kit for Christmas for my 7 year old son.  This proved to be a great kit!  I definitely appreciated the fact that shipping and costs were included with the initial purchase. (There are other kits where this is not the case).  The directions were very clear, and my son was able to utilize the suggestions given as to what, or who, to write his book about.  I LOVE the book he created with this kit.  When we got his finished product in the mail, I was pleased at the durability of the cover, binding and slightly heavier weight pages. His dream of becoming (a very muscular!) Seahawks QB are illustrated and written for us to keep forever!

WE are still working on our story, but my daughter is so excited about publishing her own book.  There are lots of extra pages if they need to start over.  Recommend having your child write story first and then put in illustration.  My daughter spent a lot of time on a picture and then added text.  She messed up on the text and was upset she couldn't start over since the picture was already drawn on that page.
Bought this item for my son's 8th birthday!  He really enjoyed it - great purchase.  Only complaint - make sure you have additional markers for illustrating ... they tend to run dry very quickly.

What a fabulous idea.  Not only is it a keepsake forever, but the kids love the idea of publishing and illustrating their own book. Our kids, ages 7 and 8, thought it was a magnificent idea. Very creative, educational and just overall awesome.  The kids really worked hard as they knew it would be a "forever" book. Three thumbs up if I had three. Great and innovative idea. An excellent keepsake to look back over the years.

I purchased this kit to make a Christmas present.  I coordinated the kids while they wrote and illustrated a story for Grandpa and Grandma.  I paid extra for rush processing and premium shipping.  The finished book arrived in about three weeks (not bad for December).The Grandparents loved their book.  And, the kids really enjoyed telling them all about the writing process.  The entire experience was very enjoyable.I bought the "Christian Edition" because it was cheaper.  It's basically the same as the regular version, with an added sheet of paper listing some Bible stories as plot ideas.  BTW, the kids didn't end up writing a Bible story.  Instead they opted to create their own tale from scratch.I would recommend this product very highly.  The quality is pretty good (considering the price).  The concept is what impressed me most.  It's a great idea that really hits the target.
summary: A great present for Grandpa and Grandma

reviewText: My granddaughter loved this opportunity to write her own book and her mother was also quite pleased.  It's a great start for a young, promising author to get their feet wet, and make their parents proud. :)
Bought this as a gift for Christmas. My daughter and Grand daughter both loved it. I didn't know until they opened it that you can send it off to be bound as a book.

I homeschool and I'm always looking for new ways to introduce subjects.  I like these cards because they are a great way to open a dialog from a Biblical standpoint.  The card gives you a summarized Bible story, followed by a conversation question.  For example, one of the cards tells the story of Simon from Cyrene helping Jesus carry his cross to Golgotha.  The question then is asked: "What is the most important thing you have ever done to help someone?"  There's a wide range of possibilities with these cards.  They're great if you want to continue talking about Simon or why Jesus had to die or go on to the topic of helping someone.  There are no wrong answers and no special knowledge of the subject is needed.While it's geared for all ages, not all the cards fit all age groups.  Some questions are more geared to children and some to adult.  For example, one of the cards asks, "To whom do you tell your secrets?" while another asks, "If you had a year's salary to give to a cause, what would you choose?"  Still, it would be simple to adjust the wording to make it fit whatever age you're talking to.
summary: Pick A Card And Let's Talk!

reviewText: Binding is a bit thin, like it had been sitting in a box for 2 years, but otherwise its nice.The quarters fit tight, some so tight a kid cant get them in. But rather have tight than loose.

reviewText: This is exactly what I expected, based on the the seller's description. Not an expensive, leather bound album or anything so fancy, but a nice looking, well organized album for collecting and safeguarding the 50-quarters set. The confirmation of sale and the confirmation of shipping were prompt and concise and the album arrived in a protective envelope in a timely manner.

My son has entered the world of collecting and he has decided on commemorative coins.  This is a great little folder to hold your coins (obviously it doesn't come with the coins) but know that it doesn't have slots for both the Denver and Philadelphia mint.  But, for a little kid's collection, it does a great job for the small price of $3.00.
Bought this for the grandchildren for Christmas. I bought uncirculated coins for each of them to fill this folder. It's sturdy enough to last their lifetime if they are careful.

I spent the last few years collecting one of each of these new coins and this nifty little binder has a spot for each of them.  A quick brush with metal polish and in they go.  Makes a great gift or hand me down to relatives.

My 7 year old just started collecting coins. I figured this would be an easy way for him to get started. This book is great. The coins stay securely in place. Who can beat a price like this too. At first I thought it was one of those "too good to be true for the price" things. Boy am I glad I took a chance on it. My son loves it, and it does not look or feel cheap.
I bought these for the quarters that I've been saving for 10 years.I will give the filled books to my grandsons this year as Christmas presents.The price is reasonable.
After ordering the product it arrived very quickly and it great shape. i am very satisfied with my purchase and i would order more products from them in the future.

reviewText: Merchandise was as pictured and arrived in prompt manner.  No problems dealing with this vendor.  Delivers great merchandise and very fast service.
great cheap product for the price - a little flimsy for a serious collector but perfect for a ameature collector just looking for a nice place to store your coins.

The folders are great for the coins we collected for our daughters over the years. They display the coins beautifully and it was easy to place the coins into the folders.  I would recommend this to anyone looking for one for kids to use.
I have enjoyed placing the coins in the books. I need more time to complete both of the books I bought.
This 50 state commemorative quarter folder is ok, because of the fine color and quality. I have bought some other folders that were not so good.
Good quality product. Will serve the purpose well for which it was intended.I ordered several folders for each of my grandchildren; they will enjoy them.
Used product arrived in excellent condition as stated in ad. Received in a couple of days.
I guess I have to say something about every thing as it comes up really didn't want to as I feel the same about all of it.

fine for what we needed. Had others like this in the past.Good for G-kids to start collecting and learning states.

The guys are so kind to solve the problem of the delivery. And the collectors are very nice. I just got the right one for my collection
Bought this as a gift for the nieces and nephews. Like most kids today, they don't notice some simple things. Hope to give them something interesting to do besides video games.
It's a very nice folder it was the way it was described. The only thing was that the book was kinda flimsy and it could probally rip if you don't handle it gently. Other than that i liked it.
It was just what I was looking for - I will be ordering at least one more - loved how fast it got here.
I had duplicate state quarters and wanted to have another album to keep them in order. The product came as described and was in excellent condition.
I bought for my friend. I enjoy the process that put the coin into the folder~~~~ My friend love this item.
Totally happy with the product.  My wife and I bought these and filled them with the state quarters for each of the grandkids.Coins fit snuggly and the album folds nicely.Good item.

and others are very easy to push in.  I think that if I pushed real hard, I might go right thru and open a hole to the other side.  So I am careful and so far, so good.

I purchased this because my original one was wet due to water damage at home, I like it better then the original!

I am not a serious coin collector, but I wanted to have the complete collection of all the commemorative quarters.  I chose this folder because it is small (6" x 8 "), thin and attractive.  It has an understated elegance about it, unlike some bigger, flashier ones I've seen.The inside front cover details a little of the history of the quarters for future generations. Then, the quarters are grouped by year in the order they came out.The panels are made of cardboard and the cutouts are just the right size for the quarters.  They fit easily and don't fall out.This is a nice folder for my quarters and I'm glad I got it.

When I looked at my order summary, I was being charged $124.75 for shipping and handling!! ($4.95 each folder!!)What a rip-off for shipping! nothing fancy, just the standard cardboard holder for your coins. only one side visible, does not have spaces for DC or territories, but does have 2 spaces that could be used

Clean and right for the price. Only disappointing is the back cover is a bit thin. Not a big deal if carefully enough.

reviewText: This is the second one I bought. All the quarters fit in very well and firm. Cheap yet good quality.

it was nicely wrapped,it was here a day early which was nice.... it looked very nice... i'm very happy with it...

This was like what I thought it would be and serves the purpose.It will make a great gift for my granddaughters with the collection of quarters already included.I just wished it would have been a little more sturdy.
Came early! Got seven for he grand kids and they were very happy. Filled them with all of the quarters I'd been saving.

New "collector", and this was 2of2 first purchases. I love the weight/size of the folder. I wasn't expecting it to be as small as it was, but happy to have folder that fits nicely into bookshelf. This isn't really a bad set at all. It helped me a lot during my Organic Chemistry class and you just have to snap the pieces together correctly. The only con with this set is that some of double bond pieces can get "locked" (there is a lock feature on the bond) in place and you have to look to see if it is locked. Other than that, it served me well and it's time for me to pass this set on!
This is a fun game to play with a group of friends in any setting. A great buy and great deal.

reviewText: This is just such a fun game. Our kids have enjoyed this game for a long time and it never gets old. We play it in the car even without the cards to help us. Gets the imagination going!

We bought this for my son for Christmas and over the two week break from school he read the questions everyday! We have finished the deck and had a lot of fun discussing the different situations. I would highly recommend this game to any family just don't take it to seriouslly.
fun game to play with a bunch of people. Great way to get to know each other. Great for a big group.

A great educational fun board game.  The board folds into thirds, so it is long enough to make a good ladybug path.  Each player's piece is a ladybug of a different color.  You draw a card when it is your turn and follow the directions on the card. Some of the cards tell you to go so many spaces forward or so many spaces backwards. The forward and backward cards each have a number on them and arrows telling you which way to go (a green left arrow is forwards and a red right arrow is backwards). If the card has a picture of a ladybug on it, you draw another card and follow those instructions. You might land on a space that gives you similar directions. If you draw a card that says you get 6 aphids, it has a number "6" on it and a picture of an aphid on the card, so you don't have to be able to read to play.  At one point, there is a stop sign on the game with a picture of an ant next to it.  You have to stop on that space (even if your card says you can move more spaces) and you have to pay the ant 10 aphids to move forward.The reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 is because the aphids are made of thick paper and could be made a little sturdier.  Even plastic coated thick paper (like playing cards) would help.  I would recommend putting all of the aphids in a small baggie to keep them together.  It comes with 2 rubber bands for the cards, but nothing for the aphids. It could also use more aphids.  The first time we played, we played with just one adult and one child and used more than half of the aphids, so if you had 4 people playing (there are 4 moving pieces) you could easily run out of aphids. The playing pieces were also too large if 2 people landed on the same square, which is not a big deal, but could have been easily fixed when the game was designed.
summary: Fun, Educational, but some of the parts could be sturdier

reviewText: Bought this for a 17 year old girl.  Cards are probably more appropriate for tweens or younger teens, esp with today's technology, these cards just didn't hold an older teens interest.
summary: Great for tweens/young teens...not so much for older kids

reviewText: great for ont he road game! THis made conversation super easy, and makes you think about things that are possibly endless. It shows your knowledge of rationalization and logic :)

I got this for my children at Christmas for a family game, but we didn't get around to it right away.  I opened it to use it as an ice-breaker activity for a new Bible-study class and it was a HUGE hit!  We were all laughing and having a great time reading these ridiculous questions to one another.  I took it home and played it with the kids and they had a blast, too.  Good, silly fun.
I didn't realize that this was just a little card game (no bigger than a deck of cards). And my grand-daughter already had a copy.

Lots of giggles and some serious questions. most interesting game. We were dining at Denny's restaurant and the kids menu had a "sampling" of the game on the placemats. We had fun while eating and decided to get the card game.
This adult version is better than kids version.  Questions aren't as crude and silly.  Great way to get the whole family involved in late night conversations around the kitchen table!  We love it.

This is a really fun conversation starter, especially on car rides. When we started playing it, we put the little tokens back in the box and never looked at them again. We found it a lot more fun to just ask and laugh at the responses and justifying why you would pick one over the other. Our games usually wandered off the cards whenever someone thought of something, but if you were stuck you could use the cards.I would recommend a purely cards-only version, no tokens or 'rules' just give us the scenarios.
My daughter loves these cards.  However, I thought the price seemed high for the number of cards that are included.
This game is fun at first, so when new friends show up that have never played it...it is fun.Not something you're going to spend hours playing.Decent game for a good price.

reviewText: While on vacation my kids' got hooked on the Would You Rather Questions that we found.  So we got the card game for home to play as a family.  It's fun to play with the whole family!

Do not buy!  There are bound to be better chemistry model sets out there, although I have not tried any others.  While it wouldn't be that bad if it actually worked right, the double bond tubes are absolutely useless because they are made way too small to fit onto the atoms!  The tetrahedral atoms are designed poorly, causing the pieces to fall off completely with no force.  The fasteners feel cheap, and many do not twist properly.  The book looks like it was typed on a typewriter int he 1970s.  Did these guys even test this kit out before deciding to sell it?As I was typing this review, I accidentally lightly bumped the cyclohexane molecule I was building and another piece fell off.  Buy at your own risk!

I bought this game for myself for in the car to pass the time. I love it, it is definitely a conversation starter and fun. I also bought the travel game and the board game for gifts also. All Arrived fast and well packaged. If you are looking for a fun game this is one, they also have children and adult options. I would get more for gifts and probably will for Christmas. I am doing family gifts this year with games, snacks, drinks, and treats in a basket. Also great for camping, family night, game night with friends....The only reason it is rated low in the educational is because you learn more about the people playing than than a literal aspect.

reviewerName: L. J. Peschken "Retired Home School Mom"
reviewText: You've Gotta Be Kidding is a card game for children from 7-11. However, adults found it fun too.  We played during our Thanksgiving weekend this year.  Three of my grandchildren participated (ages 4, 6 and 11).  Of course, we had to simplify the questions a little and choose questions they would understand.  My two adult sons really liked it, one said their family was talking about the game on the way home.  It's a fun game and a little absurd....that's when everyone starts to laugh. Excellent game!
This is a fun game to play with friends and family. It's quick, portable and quite fun. Laughter is in the air!

I had gotten this card game for my grandchildren who love to play games, but the questions in this game are just stupid and we didn't even finish one round.  An example would be, "Would you rather eat eye balls from an aligator or from an elephant?"  This was not a fun game for our family at all.....maybe if you were all drunk, you might find humor in it, but I would not recommend it to anyone.
Cute card game, great for traveling with teens or other adults.  We travel by car a lot and this game is small enough to keep in the glove box and have on hand when the boredom sets in.
summary: Would you rather be bored in the car or entertained?

reviewText: I use this with Middle School students and they are always asking me to play if we are on a trip or have some free time - a good investment!

a fun social game for kids. Seems best geared towards later elementary and middle school, but high schoolers would probably also get a kick out of it. I'm a therapist, and use the game as a conversation starter. Works every time.

We played this game as a family over Thanksgiving.  There should be a way to randomize which question is asked off every card.  Otherwise, what happens is children in the 8-11 year old age range ask all the questions that have to do with nudity and/or bodily functions.  The fun quickly pales for adults.If we were playing it again, we would probably set up a randomization system -- colored straws or colored disks to draw, and then ask the question.Some of the discussion is fun, and I think some of the value of playing with a family is that older people can sort of show younger people how decisions can be complicated.
This was a stocking stuffer for my husband and we have yet to use it but it's kind of an odd game and you lose interest in it kind of quickly.

I purchased this game but will be returning it because I didn't think some of the topics were okay.  Some were gross and others were really just inappropriate and would probably offend even the most open minded person.  I wanted this game for some teens I work with but would have to omit too many questions for this game to be useful.  I don't like crude humor but people that do like it may find it enjoyable.  I wouldn't recommend this for use with pre-teens or teens.  Adults may find the items okay but some made even made my husband cringe.
summary: Not appropriate for what I wanted it for

reviewText: At our house we love to play games.  We added this to our collection and it has been a hit so far! My kids love to play it.
Great family car game.  Keeps the conversation going and you  do not need any batteries!!!  Great questions that make you think and consider actual  scenarios.

My sister gave a set of these cards to my niece this Yule and we sat around playing it under the tree.  We ended up laughing so hard we were crying!  It was crazy.Gameplay:This cards-only version has pretty streamlined play.  Choose a card, select one of the four questions on the card and use the tokens marked 1 & 2 to either vote for your own answer or to guess what the rest of your fellow players will vote for as their answer.  We found the gameplay rather awkward when we voted on our own answers, so we stuck with the "majority rules" version.  Ask the question aloud and enjoy the debate as your friends try to agree if they'd rather... for example find out that their house lies on an earthquake fault OR an Indian burial ground.Appeal:While me and my nieces enjoyed the silly, outrageous and, yes, often gross questions, not everyone will find it amusing.  Should repeated questions about body odor or dangerous stunts offend you, you'll hate this.  Most of the cards contain at least one question of a seriously unappealing nature, but it's fun if you're not uptight.Overall:If simple-minded silliness is what you're looking for and you don't want the bulk or bother of the full-blown board game, this pack of cards could be right for you.  A good icebreaker and not a bad little distraction if you should find yourself bored with a couple of silly and open-minded friends.  Just don't be surprised if, during a lull in your discussions about the relative merits of swimming in a three piece suit versus running in a suit of armor, you find that the people around you (who aren't "playing") are discussing the same thing.  This game and the odd questions it asks are hard to ignore!
Great for in the car and as a conversation starter....usually leads to us making up our own questions....some questions are gross but we use those to discuss "appropriate vs. inappropriate" topics
The whole family really enjoys sitting around together and learning more about each others' weird quirks.  Great for parties, too.

I play this game with my students at school and with my siblings. Even us adults think it's a very fun game with some of the funniest/hardest/grossest questions.! We never actually play the game with the instructions that came with it because it's sort of boring to try and guess what that person would choose. We use the cards as just some bored questions to ask each other. sort of like truth or dare but we're not dumb enough to actually do any of these things.!
summary: Great for adults and kids alike.!

reviewText: Some of the "rathers" are pretty gross, perfect for a group of 8+ year olds.  They still talk about about the game and other's responses.  Is a huge hit.

I used to own the big version of this game and would use it in my counseling office as an ice breaker or deescalation tool.  I didn't really need to whole game and big box, so I ordered this version to just have some cards.  Kids love it!  (Best for adolescents.)

The game is fun to play with my grandson.  The cards themselves were in perfect condition and arrived quickly, however, I doubt the pack was factory-sealed as advertised.  The box had a slight tear at the top.  All in all, a good purchase.

These cards are great for kids and adults.  My entire family enjoyed reading and answering these at our family reunion and we went through the cards more than once on the road too.  :)  Good entertainment.

We bought this years ago. Absolutely love it. I have even used it for an "ice breaker" while teaching Sunday School. My daughters have played in with there friends during sleep overs. reviewText: My 16 year old and a bunch of his friends think the game is a riot and have played it for 6 or 7 hours at a time. I've played it for an hour or so a couple of times with them and though that's not enough time to make any headway in the game, I can understand why these kids find it so funny. The numerous rules are simple to remember - all you do is go from room to room or different floors to fight monsters, plus the cards have wacky, but clean humor.Kay Divi
summary: Order of the Stick Adventure Game The Dungeon of Durokan

reviewText: I adore this comic, but this game just leaves me angry every time I play it. It can take a long time, and you have little incentive to do well, because becoming awesome and fighting Xykon (final boss) just means that your friends will heap endless monsters on you until your loss - as in, you getting LAST PLACE -is assured. Belkar is literally designed to be played like a jerk. Many games strike a fun cooperative-cometitive balance, but this one absolutely does not.

I bought this game for my son as a Christmaspresent, that he picked out. As a family, wefound it entertaining. However, it is for teens/adults.I found it easier to play and learn compared to othergames with cards similar to this one, making it a plussince people are so busy these days.

I've played this a few times now and have had a blast each time!  The quick rules worked fine for us the first time, and as questions came up, we read more.  It's definitely more involved then your average board game, but if you like strategy games, you're probably going to like this!  I'd call it a blend of Talisman and Munchkin.I love how different the characters are for game play, and that each time you play you'll have a very different experience.Definitely helps if you like the comic, but I even played with 2 13-year-olds who had never heard of the comic or D&D; and they vowed to save their allowance to buy their own copy!Great game!  Highly recommended!
Ordered at the kids request, keeps them busy for 2-3 hours, they really get involved in this game when they play.
its the one game that the younger and older kids can play together.  New players can pick it up quickly.  Lots of fun

The game feels quite straightforward to play after reading the introduction comic, but there are a lot of issues that become unclear as you play the game.  The full rulebook + errata does not always make it easy to find the answer to your questions, but so far all the answers have been there.For the reviewer that couldn't get to the last level of the dungeon, players can keep meeting monsters as long as they end their movement in an empty room, so one can keep getting loot as long as no one is hoarding the loot, and one can keep trading loot back and forth for help.  Further the help bonuses stack, so it's possible (and even automatic) to take out very high level enemies.The poor durability score is due to the plastic holder in the box being already cracked right after unwrapping it.  It holds everything in place well, but I don't see how it could have broken in transport.As a big fan of the comic strip, I enjoy the game a lot, although I see the problems with the rules and gameplay.
summary: fun if you like the comic

reviewText: I Love This Game It's Very Different From Others I Love The RPG Overall It's The BEST (instead of dnd)
My 8 year old daughter loves this game, pointless fun and great for travel. Glad i bought thisIts one of her favorite games
summary: Kids + Gross = Tons of giggles and fun

reviewText: My daughter likes ducks which is why she wanted the game. She is a smart 9 year old, and found the play to be more difficult than expected. The ducks are cute, and the game is played by drawing cards which direct the duck toward drains where they collect chips. The first duck to collect 3 chips and make it back to the center wins.What was unexpectedly challenging was helping my daughter understand how the ducks move around the board (tile cards you place together to form the game surface). After about a half hour of play she got the hang of it -- to move kids should have strong spatial relationships skills as the ducks move on hexagon shaped spaces, and the direction you move and the direction you face after moving are determined by the card you play. Children with difficulty understanding spacial relationships and logic may have difficulty with this game.
summary: Good game for logic / spatial thinking

reviewText: This is a very cute game.  Even though it is meant for kids over 6 you can definitely find things to do with little ones

I love the game, and the shortening rules provide excellent options to speed up and time limit a game that before took way to long.  My one disappointment is the really cheap/thin plastic inside the box.  The box itself was packaged perfectly by amazon with no marks on it, but inside the plastic separators were all torn up.  I will have to find a different container to keep my cards separated in.
summary: Awesome game, terrible packaging inside the box

reviewText: Arrived Damaged

This game is a lot of fun! And it's funny! (I love the cards that parody D&D; spells, and most of Elan's cards are so silly, like "Gratuitous Nudity".) You don't even have to know the comic to enjoy it; one of my friends loves this game, and she's never read the comic. Then again, all my friends who have played this with me have been from my Dungeons and Dragons group, so it's probably to be expected that they'd enjoy a game that's based on a comic that's a parody of D&D.; The characters that you get to play are the members of the Order of the Stick: Roy (the intelligent, lawful good, easily annoyed human party leader), Haley (the second in command- she's a loot-obsessed, chaotic good human thief), Elan (the moronic, cheerful, chaotic good human bard/swordsman), Durkon (the good, rather bland, dwarven cleric), Belkar (the probably-evil, bloodthirsty halfling), and Vaarsuvius (the good, gender-ambiguous elven wizard). The point of the game is to move into rooms (room cards get put on the table to create a map, or a kind of "Clue" board) and kill enemies to get their treasure, or "loot" as the game calls it. You can also attack other players for loot, but my group has its own house rules where we ignore that rule; so far no one playing Belkar has wanted to attack the others, and the rest of the characters don't really need to attack any of the other players.In the game the characters all have their strengths and weaknesses, but balance out pretty well against each other; in theory, Roy and Haley would seem to be the best at the game since they're the ones with the most powerful attacks, but the other characters have just as good a chance at winning the game since beating the final boss (Xykon) isn't what determines the winner- the winner is the person with the most shticks (attack, stealing, and action type cards) and loot cards (these would be the equivalent of gold or money). The trick is to not let the other players pull ahead in how many of these cards they have.For instance, I've read reviews online where people think Haley is too strong; the trick there would be to follow her around and stay on the same floor as her so she asks for help (since the loot without her face on them don't do her any good other than as bribes) instead of letting her go off on her own floor and kill things by herself, hence getting all the loot and making her start getting more powerful shticks where she won't need much help. Also, I've found that players really need to pay attention when there's a Haley in the game; when I played her, no one realized how often I was coming in and stealing their kills and loot until it was too late, which they could have somewhat prevented by not letting her get so powerful early on (make sure you kill an enemy before she can get there, and help, help, help!).It also depends on the luck of the draw- what cards you get, how much loot you can snag in the beginning, and how many shticks you can get early on. I've kicked butt as Elan when I lucked out in getting lots of cards early, but last time someone played Elan without making him follow the other characters, so he ended up falling way behind on loot cards and shticks (the point of Elan is to help other and get loot that way, but you can't do that if you're not on the same floor as the other players). Really, you have to strategize and use what works best for the character you're playing, and everyone has an equal chance at winning.The other problem I've read about in reviews is how long the game runs. It tends to run about 4 hours for my group; we've gotten the game down now so don't have to keep looking up the rules, but when we first started it took longer. But what my group does if the game starts to run long is to make up house rules- for instance, make it be three floors instead of four, or only need six shtick cards at the end instead of eight. The Board Game Police aren't going to come after you if you change the rules up a bit. ;)This game is an awesome alternative to Dungeons and Dragons when some of the group can't make it (since my group doesn't play D&D; if more than one person can't make the game). It also runs about the same time as our D&D; game, which is perfect for us.
summary: Fun game based on a funny comic

reviewText: We purchased this game on the recommendation of a GM in a reputable game store in the Twin Cities, MN. I explained that we intended to use the game for a birthday party with a group of 11-13 year olds and wanted something that wouldn't be too competitive. (We actually have one 11 year old and the rest are 12 and 13. The box is clearly labelled 12+)As we were opening the box, the first thing I noticed in the quick start instructions was a reference to being transported to a "strip club". Hmmm... Ok. I can explain the game to the boys without reading that part of the instructions. So, I keep going...Next is a whole stack of cards labelled, "Screw this!". The intent according to the instructions is to modify the game play as the game is being played. To play one you're supposed to loudly shout, "Screw this" and slam the card down on the table.Fortunately the birthday party is still a week away and there is time to substitute. Maybe we'll just go back to Dominion.We never did play the game. So, I can't comment on the quality of the game play.The quality of the packaging is pretty poor as well for a game in this price category.

We've added this to our rotation of games for the family. As the other reviewer mentioned, your kids need to understand (or be willing to learn) spacial relationships. If you have gamers in the family, they should pick up on the game VERY quickly (even the younger ones). The ducks just add to the fun. And since I travel to shows a lot, I try to bring back a different duck or two for their collection. And if you're just a duck collector, this game is fun even without kids. It's quick and good for those days when funds are low and boredom is high.

Great game, guaranteed for hours of fun (added value if you know the comic). When you read the advice to play the game on a large surface head this advice! the game will take up a lot more space then you initially might think
Game came complete with bags for all of the (many) small parts, very convenient.  I didn't think the game was even available yet.

this is a good game for when your tabletop group has too many players missing and you all still want to hang out and play games. with the possible exception of a few of the cards (and excluding these only if you consider yourself extremely conservative), this would also be a fun game to play with children, provided they can learn the rules. the cards are of good quality and well-illustrated.this, like monopoly/risk/etc, is one of those games you can make alliances with other players and then betray them (and there is incentive for this), so be prepared for possible hurt feelings if certain people you know can't handle that.

This is a very fun train/freight game for games into these kind of games. It doesn't take several hours to play and can be a bit difficult the first few times playing. But once you've gotten used to it, it moves a bit faster. Lots of fun and strategy is a must!
Game play is fast and easy to follow. Can finish a typical match in 5-10 minutes most of the time. Great way for parents and kids to enjoy wrestling and learn about its past legends together.
Strangely categorized by Amazon.  This is the board game and not a book!Great fun!  An ideal game for your fellowship, growth groups, or other church meetings.

I wanted to do a review for this game, because my opinion differs quite a bit on this game from the person below me. True, I began playing this game not really expecting it to be that great after awhile. In fact, it felt like there were certain things that felt suspiciously similar to games like Munchkin.After giving it a real go, however, I had a very enjoyable time, and before I knew it, 3 hours had gone by. This is one of those games that is hard to recommend to certain people. I'm a pretty hardcore gamer, and I had fun with this, but I don't think it's for everybody. If you like RPG parodies like Munchkin, this will probably be up your alley. The only major difference is that you play as a specific character who gets specific items each game. It isn't as random.But while this game is meant to be light-hearted and fun, it can sometimes be very punishing in difficulty. Yes, sometimes it's the luck of the draw (most results will be based on a 1-12 die roll), but you can also get help from your friends on defeating monsters. That is, if they don't stab you in the back while they're at it.Sure, this game may never be nominated for any game of the year awards, but I feel it does a good job of trying to accomplish what it sets out to do. It's just that there may be games more suited for people who want to play games of this genre. The one thing I will say that I loved about this game though is that it gave me enough freedom to choose from fighting monsters, stealing items from other players, exploring the dungeon, searching for loot, teaming up against other players, and laughing at all the silliness that was going on. So if you don't take your games too seriously, and want something a little more light-hearted, I would recommend picking this one up. Below I'll list some pros and cons I found from playing this:Pros:+ Light-hearted fun for gamers of all experience levels.+ Lots of ridiculous humor specific to each character. They all feel fully fleshed-out.+ The game is different every time you play.+ Expansion pack adds some nice cards, including a variation that makes the game much shorter.+ There is really no way for anyone to "die" or "lose." Everyone is in the game the entire time without any significant penalties if you DO lose all your HP.+ "Backstabbing" other players never feels like anyone is out to get you. That is, unless you do it to others too much...+ One of the few games that is appealing to the non-gamer girlfriend crowd.Cons:- A lot is left up to chance.- Can amount to a pretty long game, even with just two players.- Appeals to a certain niche of gamers. Not every hardcore or casual gamer will probably enjoy this.- Certain rules can be a little difficult to grasp at first- Some monsters are far too common. The idea is that monsters of the same type give each other bonuses, but I would have preferred more variety.
summary: If you enjoy RPG parodies, this game is probably for you

reviewText: Six superb examples of the White Wings range. Please construct carefully and handle delicately. Absolutely delightful and accurate indoor airplanes.Amazing aerodynamic ability and fantastic performance.

For the price this was one of the best christmas presents I got for my boys this year. They are 11 and 7. Their father and they play this game weekly. The rules are easy enough for the 7 year old and challenging enough to be fun for the 11 year old and their dad. Some games are so boring you don't want to play with your kids, but this game is fun for all ages. It is a card game with dice and counters. It is a little lengthy to play, but lots of fun to hear everyone's best evil laugh with the Muh-ha-ha cards. We loved it.
I don't think this game is for real stoners the instructions are confusing we tryed to play the game a few times thinking we might get the game but we dident its ok.
This game is great. Simple and fun. Get two packs if you have more then 3-4 people as it goes too quickly. My friends love it and all ask where I got it.
I bought it as a gag gift, everyone laughed and it's a little confusing at first to play...but it's funny. :) Arrived quickly and matched the description. Would recommend
Fun as hell :-) The game arrived quickly, seller had good service, and good pricing. If you want a good, quick party game, try it. For more than 3 people, I'd suggest buying 2 packs, though.

My teacher actually introduced my class to this game in high school. I have been playing it for a good 6 or 7 years now and still have a blast playing every time. This is NOT just a game for stoners. It is simple, and makes for a great time with friends! Definitely get two decks so you can play with more people as the limit with one deck is four people. Would recommend this game to anyone and everyone!
This is possibly the funnest most simple easy to learn card game ever.You should buy it, get high with your friends, and then play it.

This is game is simple, but great and a lot of fun! I bought two packs to be able play with more people. My friends even invented a pontuation method so we can play a lot of rounds to see who is the winner.
I liked this item alot. But compared to the regular game....This one just doesnt match up. It is fun though and it keeps ya entertained. I play it often, but not as much as the original.
Always play this when we have people over.  Really fun game.  Today I just picked up Deluxe Weed! card game that has 7 more different character cards.  Can't wait to play!

These cards are in a category that stands alone.  They are not in the traditions of Tarot, Lenormand, or an Oracle deck.They are not play things.Recommend for use by the seriously centered and spiritually aware.

We are huge fans of trivia games, trivial pursuit/cash cab, are both regulars at most of our family get togethers so, it was fun to add to the mix! We also received it really quickly after purchasing!

Legends of Wrestling the Card Game is a 1-2 player table top game using wrestler cards, action charts, and dice. This game uses the same rule set as Champions of the Galaxy, a sci-fi themed futuristic wrestling league (if you like comics then CotG will be right up your ally). The game plays best when you book your own events, create your own feuds, and crown your own champions. Filsinger games has an active online community where people share their feds and talk everything wrestling and game related.The intro set includes 24 wrestler cards including: The Road Warriors Hawk and Animal, Nick Bockwinkel, Harley Race, Ted DiBiase, Jimmy Snuka, King Kong Bundy, Buddy Rogers, Bobo Brazil and several more. A match can last only seconds, or the longest match I've played was about 17 minutes. You start out with two wrestler cards (or four in a tag match) and roll to see who goes first. Each wrestler card has 3 levels of offense, and 3 levels of defense. Each level has six actions. The match always starts on level one. Say wrestler A rolls a 4. He looks under Level 1 Offense and number it says something like "4-Body Slam-1". The number after the move means that his opponent rolls on level 1 defense. There will be either 1,2, or 3 following a move. The bigger the move, the higher the level of defense the opponent rolls on. The defense is set up the same way, say the opponent rolls a 3 and his L1 defense says "3-hurt-2". Then the other wrestler rolls on level 2 offense because of the "-2" following the result. There are reversals too, say wrestler B rolls a 5 and it says "WRESTLER NAME-2", the move is blocked or reversed and he takes over on level 2 offense. The match continues this way until a wrestler is pinned, counted out, or disqualified. Some moves make use of the charts like when a wrestler is thrown into the ropes, out of the ring, into the turnbuckle, death jump (this is high risk moves, usually top rope moves), pin saves, wrestler or manager interference, or specialty matches. These charts require you to roll two dice and match the result with a column on the chart matching the wrestlers rating. Each wrestler has "PIN" under level 3 defense, followed by a number. He rolls two dice, and if it's equal to, or lower than his pin rating the match is over. If the match is not over, then he adds one to his pin rating and the opponent rolls again on level 3 offense. Each wrestler has a finisher, some even have two. They are always numbers 5 and 6 on level 3 offense. These add to the opponents pin rating, it will say something like: "6-FIGURE FOUR LEG-LOCK(+2)" When a wrestler rolls a finisher, the opponent automatically rolls his pin and adds the number from the finisher to it.Filsinger Games now has several wrestling games. Newer wrestling feds like Ring of Honor, NWA Championship Wrestling from Hollywood, and Combat Zone Wrestling have licensed sets with color cards. New game editions are constantly coming out and there is even an online version for all of the different games. Check out the website for Filsinger Games, there's even a free trial for the online game with four free cards: Rob Van Dam, Jimmy Snuka, and two characters from Champions of the Galaxy, Bloodline and Encubus.If you like wrestling and table top games, this is a great game. Come on, you know you want to be like Vince Mchmahon and run your own wrestling show.Intro box includes cards for Road Warrior Hawk, Road Warrior Animal, "Superfly" Jimmy Snuka, Harley Race, Nick Bockwinkel, Gorgeous George (with valet, Cherie Dupre), Nature Boy Buddy Rogers, Giant Baba,King Kong Bundy, Ted Dibiase, Johnny Valentine, Greg Valentine, Bobo Brazil, The Sandman, Jimmy Valiant, Johnny Valiant, Nikolai Volkoff, Iron Sheik, Frank Gotch, Killer Kowalski, Ox Baker, The Destroyer, Playboy Buddy Rose, and Red Bastein. The box also has an instrucion book, a book with wrestler bios, situation charts and two mini dice.
summary: Lace your boots, step into the ring, and don't forget your...dice?

reviewText: I bought this because I love all things chocolate.  I also love games.  The problem is that is doesn't really feel like much of a game.  The design is really well done and it is a high quality product.  I enjoyed reading the chocolate facts, but don't expect to really have a lot of fun with this.  It's more just a deck of chocolate facts.

Used this at a church function for women themed "You Know God Loves you - He Gave you Chocolate".  This was used as a trivia game with each person reading the question and choices.  After making the rounds with each participant, they then read the answer.  The most correct answers won a prize - Chocolate of course.  It was fun and a great way to meet new people.
We are huge fans of trivia games, trivial pursuit/cash cab, are both regulars at most of our family get togethers so, it was fun to add to the mix
I bought this because I needed the disc. I already had the game but you can't buy the disc separately. when I got it there was no disc. I have two identical useless games

I bought this game with one thought in mind:  "Make learning fun in my bar and beverage management class!"  I love drinks!  Coffee, Tea, Wine, Beer, Liquor, and Liqueurs.  It doesn't matter.  The history, how they are made,marketed, everything has a certain allure.  I'm greatful I found this game and the other beverage games!  I know my students will get a lot from them!Should be a great coffee table game too!

All kids (and parents)are different and my kids just couldn't "get with the program." We followed the instructions, offered rewards and prizes...interest lasted about as long as this post. I think as parents we just didn't push it enough or something. Product is well made except that ours started to slide down the wall after three months.
summary: Good product, but my kids wouldn't use it

reviewText: Using this for my 9 year old son - this is super easy to use and customize and when he outgrows it we will use it for my younger son! Great price !

My kids took right to this chart.  They got upset when I didnt have it finished.  Giving them simple chores for there age, in which they can earn rewards was a great way for mom to stop nagging to get things done and for kids to want to do things to help mom.
It's a thin piece of cardboard with 3m hooks... You can make it yourself for half the price... My 3 year old lost intrest after 3 days

The idea is great, but you will need to continually repair it.  We have had this for a couple of weeks now, and the hooks are glued on and keep falling off with only the weight of the cards, which are less than 1 oz.  Have plenty of super glue around the house.  This product is out of reach of our child, so it is not because he is pulling on it.  You would think when you pay almost $20 for something it would have some type of quality, especially when kids will interact with it everyday.  Also, it says for 3yrs. or older due to small parts, the I did it "chips" are itty bitty, and we went out and bought large size poker chips.  The company needs to make the chips larger to accommodate a child's product.
summary: Good Idea but  needs constant repair

reviewText: I bought one for my older child (now 7), and just bought another for my younger child.  The older one was completely uninterested in it, until the younger one got a chore board, because the older one is so competitive!  It works for accountability, but don't expect all the chores to actually get done.  if you want a particular chore to be finished (picking up stuff around the house is my top issue), make it worth more than one token, and that helps motivation.  The board is well constructed and the provided stickers are good.  We use about half of them, and made up about 4 more per kid (pack back-pack, find library books, put dirty laundry in laundry room).  I wish more were available to download and print at home after you've already bought the kit.

I have 2 of these sets- one for my 4 year old and one for my 6 year old. We've been using them for over a year. They help tremendously with getting ready in the morning and getting ready at bedtime.  I don't use the tokens that come with the system.  I think the instructions say it won't work without the tokens, but I found them unnecessary after the 1st month of getting used to the system.  Then they became more of a bother than they were worth.  My kids are just expected to do their cards. In the morning they must have their yellow cards done before they're allowed to play or watch morning shows & at bedtime they must have them done before our timer goes off in order to get their bedtime story (they  almost always get them done because that's a big motivator).  Now, my 2 1/2 year old has been requesting chore cards, so I'm getting a set for her. I like that you can individualize the cards.  You can choose which ones you want to use & it also comes with blank stickers so you can make up your own.  It is easy to adapt by age.  For example, my 6 year old has more cards that she's responsible for doing than my 4 year old, and my 2 year old will start out with just a few.  I've actually considered getting one for myself because it is such a good visual reminder of what has been completed and what still needs to be done. It helps me to not have to nag the kids.  I just have to remind them to "go do your cards."  The tokens might be great for some families. If you don't use the tokens, you will want some type of incentive for getting the cards done, or it will be just one more thing to nag about.
summary: Great product for chores for little ones

reviewText: we've gotten into strategy and word games in the last few years - probably have bought 15 in that time.  Some are duds that we'll never play again, but this one is fun, easy to learn/play and educational.
I recommend this to anyone starting out or those that want to brush up on fundamentals.  Great price - thanks Chesscentral!

I bought this for a learning chess player, aged 11. He loved it and "learned awhole lot". The teaching is geared for younger people. That is not to say older people won't enjoy it and learn too. It moves quickly, but not too fast to keep up. If you are one who knows how to play chess, but win very often, this DVD is for you.
Very good for person with NO knowledge of Chess.  I am not so far advanced but had hoped for a little more tactical information.

I had hoped these would keep my two girls (ages almost 3 and 5) busy on a long car trip.  They didn't really seem to like them though!  They used them a little, but they were quickly thrown to the side, where they were coated in crumbs, dust, and other "car dirt" from the long trip.  They were tossed in the garbage shortly after!
summary: Not a huge hit for my kids

reviewText: BuyWord is a word game from master designer Sid Sackson, yet it struggled to get published due to a very crowded field largely dominated by games like Scrabble and Boggle. When it finally appeared in 2004, a couple of years after Sackson's death, it went on to win Games Magazine Game of the Year award in 2005, and many consider it a "modern classic in the making".  This particular edition is the Face2Face edition, and a deluxe edition also appeared in 2011 courtesy of Gryphon Games.Let's be honest that the genre of word games isn't everybody's cup of tea. But this one is different, because it introduces a simple economy to the game. The letter tiles in the game have dots on them, and the amount of dots in a collection of tiles will determine its buying and selling price. Players first must buy tiles, and then try to sell them at a profit ideally by making large words with lots of dots.The economic element that Sackson has incorporated presents an interesting twist on the traditional point-scoring model associated with most word games, and works really well. It avoids some of the pitfalls associated with Scrabble, which can reward players for knowledge of obscure short words. The game is also very accessible for non-gamers, and has a very broad appeal. It also works outstandingly as a solitaire challenge. In BuyWord, Sid Sackson has produced a word game that deserves to be a modern classic among word games. - EndersGame @ BGG
summary: A clever and classic word game with an economic element

reviewText: Wikki Stix are good, clean fun for all. They can be used creatively or to make shapes and letters. Made in USA is a bonus!

This was a big hit with my 4 year old nephew. The first time he sat down and did the book twice.  Then he discovered all kinds of fun ways to include the wikki stix into his play, and they are not messy.The best is that it is basically string with wax.  What a creative idea!
summary: Big hit with my 4 year old nephew!

reviewText: Most products associated with Waitzkin are pretty good. This DVD is a snazzy introduction to the chess pieces and how they move. A few silly utterances by the protagonist.

As mentioned in other review of the Curious George book/Wiki Stix pack, I purchased this for my granddaughters, ages 5 and 3, for Christmas. They turned their attention to these as soon as all the presents were opened and spent a long QUIET stretch engrossed in playing with them.  Great purchase! You will want to buy more.

Wikki stix are an excellent, quiet time activity that is highly entertaining. The books are sturdy and well constructed. No need to worry about toxicity from Chinese manufacturing with this. Nice job!
Bought this at my friend's recommendation as her preschooler loved it. My preschooler did not enjoy the product as it left sticky residue on his fingers.

This is a cute book that we bought to use as a surprise on an airplane.  We bought this for my 2 1/2 year old and she still uses it 1 year later.  The stix's stay sticky after several uses.  The book does get some residue on it after each use, but that would come clean with some water or windex.
Had gotten a couple at a restaurant and the kids loved them... They create and recreate all kinds of things!

My son has been asking me for bendaroos for the longest time so i got him these since they are pretty much the same thing. i believe the only difference is that the wikkistix have an adhensive quality that lets them stick to glossy books or other shiney surfaces. the book included is very amusing and give kids creative ways to use the wikkistix. for example there is a page with under water  scenery with seaweed and such and you use the wikkistix as if they are seaweed and create other under water critters or scenery. my son wraps them around his pencils, toys, and uses them in other books. overall he has a lot of fun with them and it allows him to express some creativity. the other day he made me "heart balloons" with them. my 2yo mimics what he does and they can play together easily without fighting over them since there are many.
I got this for my best friends little girl when she turned 4 years old in February.  She absolutely loves these Wikki Stixs and spends hours creating interesting things with them.
My grandchildren live in London and often fly over here to the US.  These are a great item to take on a plane or in a car for that matter. So are post it pads!
summary: GREAT Item for traveling with kids

reviewText: First, Amazon really rose to the occasion when this gift was somehow lost in the mail.  Without having to blame the USPS (whose fault we all suspected it was), they just said..."we'll ship another". And, my niece got it before Xmas!  Cheers to you Amazon for excellent client service, I will definately remember that next time I need to shop online.  Moreover...apparently the toy is really cool and my niece loves to play with it (she's 5).  Good experience all around.  Cheers!

This kept my 34 month old daughter occupied during a recent long plane trip.  I was able to pull out the Wikki Stix again and again when she got bored or restless.  It's nice and compact, not messy, and quiet.  These will be a go to toy for us again.  I highly recommend it.
These really do work! They stay sticky, easy to shape and twist the stix, too! I use it in church as a quiet book.
This came in so handy on my recent flight. Entertained my 2 year old for a good 1/2 hour.

Bought for my 3-year old for some car trips this summer.  A book and little bendy colorful sticks that don't take up too much room were perfect.  Each page has a picture and description and kids can use the books guidance along with their imagination to elaborate on the picture.

So much fun for young ones.  A nice activity for quiet time and helps build fine motor skills as well.  I wish it were a little longer and that it came with more Stix so that we could be a little more creative on each page as well.
summary: Very good quiet activity, builds motor skills

reviewText: I thought there would be dashed lines or something to show where to add stuff in the book, but basically it's just a picture book that you could stick stuff to. In addition, it didn't come with very many stix.

I got this for a six hour car drive to entertain a 4 year old boy.  It kept him busy for quite a while. I don't let my son play with car toys except when we are on long trips (they stay novel then and he is kept busy for longer requiring less frequent stops and we can keep driving) so I can't speak about durability or if the wax sticks will keep up their sticking power.  It took my son a while to realize he didn't have to follow the books directions and could make his own designs but I think that is a function of age rather than product design.  Over all I think this is a worth while purchase for travel.
This was a gift to my grandchildren and theyloved,loved, loved this so much that theyare all gone. What a way to go to have somethingthat teaches the hands to create
summary: Wikki Stix are easy to use

reviewText: Wish the book was more simple.  This was my kids first time playing with wikki stix.... they were a little lost!

This is not a long-term toy that your toddler is going to want to keep going back to play with (at least it wasn't for mine).  It kept her busy on an international plane ride and a 2 week vacation --- along with other toys of course.  She was only 2.5 at the time and really couldn't use the wikki stix like the book's pictures, but she still had fun sticking them in different positions throughout the book.  If your child is older, they might appreciate the book more.  Otherwise, for toddlers, you can get the wiki stix at dollar stores for cheaper and just use any old hard page book (so no page ripping) --- it could be just as fun.  I liked this purchase because the price was reasonable and it is a really cute hard page book that came with colored wikki stix.
summary: Great fun for a vacation and plane ride

reviewText: My 3 yr old twins love Wikki sticks. I usually break them out when we are restaurants, or any place we need a quite contained toy. They are great for airplanes to - they even stick on the windows and they don't leave any residue behind. They easily entertain my kids for at least a half an hour.
summary: Wonderful WIkkis - A great, quite toy

reviewText: I bought this Wikki Stix book for my 2 1/2 year old grandson before a long car trip.  He had a lot of fun playing with them along the way.  While he's too young yet to accurately place the stix where they are intended to go inside the book, he still loved sticking them everyone and making shapes with them.  They have a lot of play value with the various colors and the ability to make shapes, then later when he's older, he can put them on the pages where they belong.
Wikki stix are an excellent quiet time activity and easily portable. This is made in the USA, safe nontoxic fun. The book is really clever and cute. Highly recommend!

Surrounded by all the new Christmas toys, when the craziness slowed down, the first thing they went to was the Wiki Stix. The girls ages 5 and 3 loved them! I had to immediately order more because that small pack included with the Curious George (also a favorite) book was no where near enough for their imagination. Great purchase!

I bought this for my 2 1/2 year old before a plane trip and I'm so glad I did!  She enjoyed sticking the Wikki Stix to the pages in the book, but also enjoyed making other stuff with them.  They kept her occupied for nearly an hour, which is saying a lot!  I'll definitely be buying more of these in the future!
summary: Great to occupy a kid on an airplane!

reviewText: You and your kids will have countless hours of interesting creations with these while waiting at restaurants, on trains, etc.  I'd recommend getting a few packs.  They hold up quite well but over time lose their stickiness.A bargain.

reviewText: This was great to distract/occupy my 3-year old twins on a 1.5 hour plane ride.  They spent at least 30 minutes playing with this book and another I purchased.  Thirty minutes for a three-year old is AMAZING.  I could not have asked for more.  FYI, I like the wiggles and squiggles Wikki Stix book a little better than this one for my just-turned 3-year olds.  The Curious George one is better for older 3-year olds, I think, although both were GREAT.
summary: Wikki Stix Books GREAT for plane travel

reviewText: When this game came I was surprised.The quality of the game construction is extremely high. It's easy to see that a lot of thought went into planning and construction.I haven't had a chance to play the game with partners yet. It looks interesting and worthwhile. I wish I could say more but I hane't had the experience yet. Judging from the quality of construction I'd say "buy it, try it, review it" so more can be known.
It was in great shape, no dings or cuts on it, shipped fast. nice job.

I bought these for my girls, 5 & 3, for travelling with over the holidays. I have to say the 3yo isn't massively interested in them (but this could have been because of multitude of other gifts received at the same time) but my 5 yo really like them. I love them as there is almost no limit to what you can do with them and there is no mess. Great for travelling, staying at hotels or other peoples houses, planes etc. Great toy for the money.

I ordered this game a few months ago as a birthday gift for my good friend. We actually busted it out at her birthday party, which was an eclectic group of people who didn't really know each other, and it was an instant hit. The Diagnosis Book is super creative. If you like witty humor, I'd definitely suggest ordering RORSCHOCK!

This game could've been kind of fun, except that the "diagnoses" are just complete nonsense. I don't mean that they're inaccurate (seeing as Rorschach tests have been relegated to the same realm of pseudoscience as dream analysis, I would expect them to be pretty weak), I mean they're *nonsense.*If you saw..."A Sumo wrestler: Stop trying to put everyone in diapers.""A double chimera: This is a conditioned emotional response to not really knowing what a chimera is much less two of them.""A light fixture: Initially you thought playing this game was a good idea. But not anymore.""The sound of a tree falling: You are clinging to an echo."Seriously....what? No one expects you to be right, but at least TRY, like all the other pretending-to-analyze-yourself-junk. Otherwise it's just totally pointless. At some point, the psychological community had some way of analyzing these tests, and it would be far more interesting to see that than utter blather.

I had to buy this after my friend had bought one for herself.  At first I was just skimming through the cards and the diagnosis book because I was bored and was curious about what my friend had purchased.  I ended up buying one that day because I couldn't put it down.The inkblots are interesting and can be revealing about how "dirty" a person's mind can be - but it's all just fun and games.

This game is worth every penny I spent for it!  I was desperate to find something to entertain a small group of friends, and someone recommended to try this game and it was a huge hit at my party.  BUY ONE NOW - you won't be disappointed!

my family loved this game...actually we just played with the cards and made up our own game...but it was fun anyway...the only problem is...its not really a game u can play over and over again...its kind a once off trick!!!...but fun nonetheless!!!

I bought these for a road trip I was taking with some friends. I thought it might be a fun way to kill some time. I was wrong on both accounts. We didn't find the ink blot or the bizarre, meaningless interpretations to be fun and it sure didn't kill any time. Two cards in and I ended up leaving this waste of my money at the hotel.

Sure, the questions can be a little silly. And some you'll answer so quickly that you'll hardly believe such a question was included. But overall, it's hilarious - especially when you get the answers wrong. Then you can smack yourself on the forehead and laugh uproariously with your friends. It's a great, fun time for everyone.

The questions on the cards were mostly stupid stumpers, where if you listen carefully you can easily see what they were trying to get you to say.  There were a few trivia questions thrown in so it was a strange mix.  OVerall it was a dissapointment because we got through the whole deck of cards in less than 30 min.  Amusing but not enough content.

I purchased this for my children (ages 10 & 12) and my husband and I. I read the reviews and thought it sounded great.  Unfortunately it didn't meet up to  my expectations. Most of the questions are silly trick questions...QUESTION "How many birthdays does the average man have?"  ANSWER " 1 "QUESTION "Some months have 31 days, how many have 28?" ANSWER "All of them".Some are good trivia questions like...QUESTION "What states border Montana?" ANSWER "Idaho, North Dakota, South Dakota, Wyoming" orQUESTION "Can you name the 5 great lakes?"If more of the questions were actually basic trivia questions that everyone should know (but a lot of people don't) it would be funny and informative but the trick questions are irritating. We didn't find them funny, just annoying.Last example...QUESTION "In Morocco, you can't take a photo of a man with a fez. Why not?" ANSWER..."Because you can't take a picture with a fez. You need a camera".
summary: Okay, if you like silly trick questions.....

reviewText: The questions on these cards are so easy that when you get an answer right you feel smarter than Einstein himself!  Get an answer wrong, you'll turn red in the face from laughing - you can't make a mistake with this game! It's fun for everyone !!

What seems to be a silly game is actually a reall good laugh in 50 cards.  This was a good way to balance the stress of finding a career with trying not to take life too seriously.  I recommend for anyone who just wants to crack a smile on their face once in awhile.

and I mean that!  I've never really found anything like this before.  Never mind career counselors or job placement tests - if you want something that will be funny and entertaining - this is the game to buy.  Game comes with 50 cards/ideas with 100 possibilities that will get you thinking your future, but with a little more sense of humor.

If you are quick-witted, love puns, and like laughing, this is the game for you. Sometimes it can be difficult to come up with funny punchlines in just a couple of minutes, but often the results will surprise you. This is a great family/party game.Don't stress out or watch the sand slip through the timer. Just let your humor juices flow and enjoy!
I bought this game for a 10 year old who loves it!I am glad I made this purchase. I recommed it for riddel loving kids.

The game looks okay, but I haven't found the time to play it yet. However, I have a small customer remark. I think it would be nicer if the box contained small card boxes as well. Now the cards are put loose into the box, which can dammage them in time. There neither is a need to have such a big box: the game can be made in a smaller size, I suspect. Because the box is so big, I hesitate to take it along with me.
summary: looks okay but design can improve

reviewText: You've probably all heard the cliched "Why did the chicken cross the road?" joke. It's an old classic that has spawned all kinds of imitations, and if you like that kind of humor, Why Did the Chicken...? is for you.The basic concept is that cards with random nouns will determine an unusual riddle, e.g. "What do a turkey and an electric guitar have in common?" or "Why is a marshmallow better than a barber?" Players are then given time to come up with witty answers, which are then voted on. Think Balderdash - but with a good sense of humour added.This is not going to work with everyone, but we love it, and when played with the right people, it can be a real blast! You need some creativity plus a good dash of humour, perhaps even to the point of zaniness, but if you can find a group like that, Why Did the Chicken...? is going to bring out their very best. If you and your friends or family find this kind of wacky humor appealing, then you definitely need to consider whether this is the kind of party game that might be for you. - EndersGame @ BGG
summary: What happens when you cross Balderdash with Apples-to-Apples, and actually make it funny?

reviewText: I own a lot of games - party, strategy, 2-player, etc...This is one of the most requested games I own.Pros:* It's a blast with the right group** It's cheap, so even if you don't love it, it won't break the bank* Did I mention it's a blast to play?Con:* If you have very quiet friends, this probably won't go over too well.  Come to think of it though, if you have a lot of quiet friends, most "party games" won't go over too well...Of note: Wits & Wagers is my groups other hotly requested game.  I believe Amazon was running a package deal on this, W&W; and another game.  Can't go wrong with these!
summary: With the right group, this is a BLAST

reviewText: Bought this last Christmas, i think - to play with my 3 kids (now 20, 17, 12) We enjoyed playing it for a couple of days; we go back to it from time to time when bored with other games. Usually end up doing 1-2 rounds (of each player being judge)...thing to be careful is when they get frustrated, in between the legitimately funny answers/quips, the kids start writing answers like "who cares"  or "nothing"...and then "this is killing me" or "doesn't ___ look very excited"  - but even those responses get us cracking up as we read them, and we end up having a good time before moving on to the next activity.....we always reach to play the game again....it's a relaxing interlude between more stressful games like scrabble - which we tend to get pretty intense with:-)

I've played this game with very diverse groups of people--folks who like word games and people who don't, people who think they are funny and people who fear they are not funny, experienced Chicken players and new-comers to the game....it's easy to learn, and amazingly is fun for all types of people.  Everytime we pull it out, I end up having a really enjoyable evening and I recommend it heartily.
summary: A real hoot--all types of people enjoy this game

reviewText: Fun game. Good for children of various ages. Creativity reigns and "winning" is subjective. It's like Apples to Apples meets Balderdash.

Why Did the Chicken...? is a clever board game.Positives: You can play for a long time; because you supply the content, the game never gets old.It is very simple to learn.While having a competitive element, winning is far from the only thing.You may funnier than you think.Negatives:  Some people don't like to have their submissions judged (albeit anonomously).Takes at least four players and a few rounds to really get the juices flowing; but, hey, it's a party game!This game is really fun and funny.  Good for budding comedians or tragically afflicted punsters.

I bought 2 of these based on the reviews, one for our family and another for a friend.  Tonight, we played with our teenaged boys and a bunch of their friends and had a blast.  I haven't laughed that hard in a long time.  I am ordering another for my niece's birthday.
